editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

div.p: As it was acted by her majesty's servants at the private house in Drury lane.
London, printed by E. A. for Francis Constable, and are to be sold at his shop in Paul's churchyard, at the sign of the cra●e. 1631.

div.head: To the truly noble gentleman, William Tresham esquire.
div.p:
Sir, I have long cherished a desire, by some worthy testimony, to express how much I honour you: but after a tedious expectation, hopeless to meet with an occasion to make me so fortunate; I resolved, rather than to hazard the censure of neglect, to snatch any opportunity of presenting my services. This (Which to me hath no name, but what your bounty shall bestow) having pleased you upon
the stage, coming into the world, offereth itself to kiss your hand. If you be merciful, I am upon even terms with the world beside, and will study next to reach your mind with imaginations of a higher nature. In the mean time, grow you up, and ripen yourself for honour; the flowings of your blood will instruct you how to merit; while I rest content with my ambition, if I may still write myself,

div.head: The school of compliment.
Prologue.
div.l: It is a principle by nature wrote
In all our understanding, there is not end.
One art or action, but it must tend
And move from some beginning to its
The soldiers that wear the honoured bays
Upon their brows, and glorious trophies raise
To fame on pile of wounds, knew a time when
They sucked at war. Your muse inspired men
And of diviner earth, sacred for wit,
Crept out of their first elements to it:
The goodliest harvest had first seed and hope,
Ere it could lade with an enriching crop
The rural team, th'exactest building first
Grew from a stone, though afterwards it durst
Wrap his fair head in clouds: nothing so true,
As all things have beginning: upon you
Dwell candid application; this play is
The first fruits of a muse, that before this
Never saluted audience, nor doth mean,
To swear himself a factor for the scene.
Though he employ some hours he only prays
You take it as first born, although he says,
He meant it not his heir, since 'tis unjust
One should have all, as in the law it must.
Accept then a beginning; all men know,
He first kissed bays, that wore them on his brow.

list.head: Dramatis personae.
list.item: Infortunio, a gentleman lover of Selina.
Antonio, son to Cornelio, in love with Hilaria.
Gasparo, a gentleman a lover of Felice.
Bubulcus, a rich gull, in love with Hilaria.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Sirrah, this Welshman is in love with my sister Selina, and hath chosen me for his prolocutor.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: O! this love will make us all mad, thou knowest I loved a sister of thine once, but heaven knows where she is, I think she loved me too, dost think she did not?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Well, thy father has reason to curse himself, beside some that she and I have.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, nay, thou'lt fall into passion again, when things are passed recovery, 'twas a good wench, but come, prithee leave to think on her.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Nay, I ha' done, what shall's do?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Any thing but talk of state matters: thou hast much intelligence in the world, prithee what's the news abroad? I come forth a purpose to hear some, and this is an age of novelties.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: News? O excellent news!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee what is't? I long to hear some.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: There is no news at all.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Call you that excellent news?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Is it not good news, that there is no bad news? the truth is, the newsmaker master Money-lack is sick of a consumption of the wit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The newsmaker? why, is there any newsmaker?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: O sir, how should younger brothers have maintained themselves, that have travelled, and have the names of countries, and captains without book, as perfect as their prayers, I and perfecter too? for I think there is more probability of forgetting their prayers, they say them so seldom; I tell you sir, I have known a gentleman that has spent the best part of a thousand pound, while he was prentice to the trade in holland, and out of three sheets of paper, which was his whole stock, a pen and inkhorn he borrowed, he set up shop, and spent a hundred pound a year upon his whore, and found sheets for them both to lie in too: it has been a great profession; marry most commonly they are soldiers: a peace concluded, is a great plague unto 'em, and if the wars hold, we shall have store of them; oh, they are men worthy of commendations, they speak in print.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Are they soldiers?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p:
Faith so they would be thought, though indeed they are but mongrels, not worthy of that noble attribute; they are indeed bastards, not sons of war and true soldiers, whose divine souls I honour, yet they may be called great spirits too, for their valour is invisible, these I say will write you a battle in any part of Europe at an hour's warning, and yet never set foot out of a tavern, describe you towns, fortifications, leaders, the strength a'th enemies, what confederates, every days march, not a soldier shall lose a hair ▪ or have a bullet fly between
his arms, but he shall have a page to wait on him in quarto, nothing destroys 'em but want of a good memory, for if they escape contradiction, they may be chronicled.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, thou art wise enough to be an informer.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: I marry, now you speak of a trade indeed, the very Atlas of a state politic, the common-shore of a city, nothing falls amiss unto 'em, and if there be no filth in the commonwealth can live by honesty, and yet be knaves by their privilege, there is not an oath but they will have money for it!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O brave trade.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: They can eat men alive and digest 'em, they have their conscience in a string, and can stifle it at their pleasure, the devil's journeymen, set up for themselves, and keep a damnation house of their own; indeed they seldom prove aldermen, yet they are taken for knights every day a'th week, when they ride post, they have the art of insinuation, and speak writs familiarly, they are agents as I have heard for the devil in their life time, and if they die in their bed, have this privilege, to be sons of hell by adoption, and take place of sergeants.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Stay. Who's there? thy sister and Infortunio: let's observe.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: I must have other answer, for I must love you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Must? but I do not see any necessity that I should love you, I do confess you are a proper man.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: O do not mock Selina, let not excellence
Which you are full of, make you proud and scornful,
I am a gentleman, though my outward part
Cannot attract affection, yet some have told me,
Nature hath made me what she need not shame,
Yet look into my heart, there you shall see
What you cannot despise, for there you are
with all your graces waiting on you, there
Love hath made you a throne to sit, and rule
O'er 〈◊〉, all my thoughts obeying
And honouring you as Queen, pass by my outside:
My breast I dare compare with any man.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 〈…〉 can see this breast you 〈◊〉 of so?

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: O 'tis an easy work, for though it be
Not to be pierced by the dull 〈◊〉 whose beam
Is spent on outward shapes, there is a way
To make a search into hiddenst passage.
I know you would not love to please your sense:
A tree that bears a ragged unleaved top
In depth of winter, may when summer comes
Speak by his fruit, he is not dead but youthful,
Though once he showed no sap: my heart's a plant
Kept down by colder thoughts, and doubtful fears,
Your frowns like winter storms make it seem dead,
But yet it is not so, make it but yours,
And you shall see it spring, and shoot forth leaves
Worthy your eye, and the oppressed sap
Ascend to every part to make it green,
And pay your love with fruit when harvest comes.
If my affection be suspected, make
Experience of my loyalty, by some service
Though full of danger, you shall know me better,
And so discern the truth of what you see not.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Then you confess your love is cold as yet,
And winter's in you heart.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Mistake me not, Silena, for I say
My heart is cold, not love.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: And yet your love is from your heart I'll warrant.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: O you are nimble to mistake,
My heart is cold in your displeasures only,
And yet my love is fervent, for your eye
Casting out beams, maintains the flame it burns in.
Again, sweet love,
my heart is not mine own, 'tis yours, you have it,
And while it naked lies, not deigned your bosom
To keep it warm, how can it be but cold,
In danger to be frozen? blame not it,
You only are in fault it hath no heat.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Well sir, I know you have rhetoric, but I
Can without art give you a final answer.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: O stay, and think a while, I cannot relish
You should say final, sweet, deliberate,
It doth concern all the estate I have,
I mean not dunghill treasure, but my life
Doth stand or fall to it, if your answer be
That you can love me, be it swift as lightning,
But if you mean to kill me, and reject
My so long love-devotions, which I have paid
As to an altar, stay a little longer,
And let me count the riches I shall lose ▪
By one poor aery word, first give me back
That part of Infortunio that is lost
Within your love, play not the tyrant with me.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You're overweak to let your passions sway you:
If I knew any thing I had of yours,
I would not do you that injustice, sir,
To let it stay with me, and for your love
I cannot pay it back again with mine,
Either release the debt, or I shall die in't,
Your suit is fruitless, hopeless, pardon me, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now by all my hopes you are to blame, sister, come, this gentleman deserves your love, Infortunio.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Brother, you forget yourself.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, I do remember I am your brother, I say you must love him.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Must?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What, does that move your spirit? what are you, but you may love? be not petulant, you're a baggage and not worthy of a man, by heaven I now could kick her.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Thy tother sister was of calmer temper, this a true woman.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Sir, had not nature made you brother to her, I should be angry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Alas poor gentleman, I do not feel myself in such an humour for Hilaria, and yet by this hand I love her well enough, and now I think on't, I promised her my company, she has a damnable usurious stinking wretch to her father, that cannot abide me, but 'tis no matter, this wench and I may find a place to meet in, in spite of his eyes and spectacles. How now Gorgon, what says she?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Sir, I have done your remembrances to mistress Hilaria, and told her you should find her coming by and by, but you were best pass in some obscurity, for her father Rufaldo is hard by sir. Lupus in fabula.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Gasparo, and thou love me, show thy wit to entertain this piece of black damask and velvet guards, while I go in to Hilaria.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Old men are the truest lovers, young men are inconstant and wag with every wind, we never move, but are as true as steel.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: But in women's matters as weak as water, as weak as water.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Besides, sweet love, but do I court a shadow? to see whither love will carry a man: let me see, I could find in my heart to bestow a ring upon my sweetheart, but that I am loath to part with it: hem, I will get but one child, and that shall be a boy, lest having too many children, I undo my heir, and my goods be divided. O sweet Selina, oh amiable Selina; sure I am not old.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: I have it, signior Gasparo, pray let me begin with my merchant if you love me, and if you 〈◊〉 it, second me.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Go to Gorgon, let's see thy window.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p:
Old men walk with a staff, and creep along the
streets, hold their heads below their girdle, falter in their speech, foam at mouth, and breathe ten times in a furlong, and are ready to spit their lungs on every man's threshold.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: God save you sir.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: God a mercy honest Gorgon.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: I cry you mercy sir, I'll assure you sir, I took you for master Rufaldo the old merchant.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Why, and am not I? is not the fellow drunk? I am Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: It may be some kin to him, but not that Rufaldo I mean, you are younger a fair deal.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I am that Rufaldo, the merchant, that buried my wife lately, and have one daughter Hilaria, ancient acquaintance with Cornelio and your master Antonio.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: O sir, you must excuse me for that.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Is thy name Gorgon?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: What else sir, honest Gorgon I?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Do I know thee to be Gorgon? what, shall I be faced out of myself? why thou varlet, who am I, if not Rufaldo?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Why sir, 'tis plain, you have no grey hairs in your head, your cheek is scarlet, a wanton youthful eye; Rufaldo had a head like frost, his eyes sunk into his hollows, a rugged brow, a hoary beard, and all his body not worth a drop of blood, a very crazy old meal-mouthed gentleman, you are younger at least by thirty years.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I'll assure thee I was Rufaldo, when I rose in the morning.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: You have not slept since, have you?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: 'Tis the more strange. I have heard of some that have been changed in a dream, but never waking before: this is strange, nay admirable!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Young, changed, art sure thou dost not mock?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p:
I were a very knave then, if you be Rufaldo, I hope
your worship knows I have been bound to my good behaviour.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Altered young, ha! I would I were; and yet methinks I am livelier than I was, I feel my joints pliable as wax, and my voice is stronger too. But tell me, honest Gorgon, is it possible for an old man to be young again?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Nay, I see you'll not believe me: well sir, I will be bold to report the wonder abroad, and astonish all your friends.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Nay, stay, honest Gorgon, ha! young, no grey hairs? stay, who's here?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Ha! 'tis not he, I'll speak to him, no 'tis in vain, I'll see if he knows me. — he passes by.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Gasparo! what, does not he know me too?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Sir, I should know you, are you not signior Petrucchio, the dancing master?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Tricks, passages, I am Rufaldo, old Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Rufaldo indeed is old, but you are young, you do retain his countenance, I would swear you were he, but you are younger far.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: 'Tis so, I am changed, I am younger than I was, I am that Rufaldo, believe, I know you to be a learned gentleman, named Gasparo, I was told afore I was altered, but not to trouble you with many questions, only one, Gasparo, is it a thing possible for an old man to be young again? I know 'tis admirable, but is it possible? you are a scholar.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Possible? o yes, there's no question, for we see by experience, stags cast their old horns, and prove vigorous, snakes cast off their old coats, eagles renew their age, your plants do it familiarly, the phoenix when she is old, burns herself to ashes, from thence revives a young phoenix again. Possible? I have heard some old men have been twice children sir, — therefore 'This not impossible.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: 'Tis very strange: I am not yet confident.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: There be receipts in physic, sir, to keep them young, saving that time runs on a little beforehand with 'em: yes, and to make young, since it is harder to make alive when they are dead, than to make young when they are alive, and physic doth revive some out of all question, though not so familiarly as kill, for that they do with a little study; marry I think, if it were as gainful to the physician to restore as to destroy, he would practise the art of recovery very faithfully.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Why, do you think it would not prove as gainful?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Oh! by no means, for where an old man would give a hundred pound, to have forty or fifty years wiped off the old score of his life, his wife or next heir would join rather than fail, to outbid him half on't, to put him out of debt quite, and to send his old leaking vessel into mare mortuum.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Well, well, but if I be young, I have taken no physic for't.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: If nay, 'tis past if, and, and too, you are certainly restored, let me see, you look like one of four, or six and thirty, not a minute above, and so much a man may take you for.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Well, I know not what to say to't, there is some power in love has blessed me: now Selina, be thou gracious.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Are you in love? nay, the wonder is not so great; who can express the power of love? I have read of a painter named Pygmalion, that made the picture of a woman so to the life, that he fell in love with it, courted it, lay in bed with it, and by power of love, it became a soft-natured wench indeed, and he begotten I know not how many children of her. Well sir, Selina cannot choose but be mad for you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Not mad, Gasparo, I would be loath to be troubled with her and she be mad.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p:
Yes, and she be mad in love, there is no harm in't, she cannot be too mad in love, your cornucopia may be
abated at pleasure, besides sir, the best moral men say, love itself is a madness, and the madder your wife is, the more sure you may be she loves you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: No, no, I love no madness on any condition, for fear of being horn-mad.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Why sir, madness is not such a discredit, as the age goes: you know there are many mad fashions, and what man but some times may be mad? are not your great men mad, that when they have enough, will pawn their soul for a monopoly? besides mad lords, what do you think of ladies at some time of the moon, you may spell 'em in their names, madam? you have mad courtiers, that run madding after citizens' wives: the citizens are mad too, to trust 'em with their wares, who have been so deep in their wife's books before: your justice of peace is some times mad too, for when he may see well enough, he will suffer any man to put out his eye with a bribe: some lawyers are often stark-mad, and talk wildly, no man is able to endure their terms.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Prithee madcap leave, I am almost mad to hear thee.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Well, my old young Rufaldo, if you marry Selina, I shall have a pair of gloves, I hope, and you'll let me dance at your wedding.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: That thou shalt, boy, and I'll dance myself too, heigh, —

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Farewell credulity; ha, ha, with what a greediness do old men run out of their wits? 'twas a good recreation to see with what pleasure he suffered himself to be gulled: faith Gasparo, play out thy hand, now thou art in: methinks I have an excellent appetite to make myself merry with the simplicity of this age: let me see, 'tis spring and, I mean to give my head a purgation, it may beat off the remembrance of my lost love Felice: a pox of melancholy, I will act two or three parts if I live in spite of it, and if I die then

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Signior Gasparo, my master would speak with you: the project too ▪ I met the youth strutting like a gentleman usher, 'twas my invention.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: But I gave it polish, Gorgon.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: I confess, you took off the roughcast, but 'twas Gorgon's head brought forth the project, from my Jove's brain came this Minerva.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: I think thou art a wit.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Who, I a wit? I thought you had 'More wit, than to make such a question, all the town takes me for a wit, here's a pate hath crakers in't and flashes.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: And thou sayest the word, we'll join in a project of wit, to make an ass of the world a little, it shall make us merry, if it take no other ways, wilt join?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: By this hand, any project of wit, what is't, good Gasparo? the project.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Canst be close?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: As midnight to a bawd, or a pair of trusses to an Irish man's buttocks.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Go to, thou shalt now then excuse me to thy master, I will presently furnish myself with new lodgings, and expect to hear from me shortly my brave Delphic, I have it in embrio, and I shall soon be delivered.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: If I fail, call me spider-catcher.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Mum, not a word, if all hit right, we may laugh all our melancholy thoughts away.

div.head: Actus secundus, scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
If I were a woman, now could I fall in love with myself: everybody tells me I am the properest gentleman in the town, and I put it up, for the truth is, I dare not give any one the lie, a pox a fighting, I can look as big
as another, but shall I be such an ass, to venture myself with beasts? for they say, your swords most commonly are foxes, and have notable mettle in 'em; let me see, I am now at Rufaldo's my father in law that must be, here he is.

div.p: Master Rufaldo, if you had been my own father, as you are but like to be my father in law, I should have proved myself a fool, by this hand I should not have known you, why, how brisk and neat, and youthful he is!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I am something altered I confess, since I saw you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: By this flesh that shines, a man would not take you to be above five or six and thirty at most, how came this?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Just as Gasparo told me, 'tis apparent, nay, nay, son, forbear to be inquisitive, I confess I am abated of my age, the power of love, and so forth, but I see your fire of love is not out too.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No, mine was but raked up in the embers.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Why, this love does make us all ingenious too: come sit down, saving your tail sir, a cushion, we may discourse with the more case.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Pray, how does my sweetheart mistress Hillaria.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: She is very well, ha son, I am in love too: son I call you, I hope you will get my daughter's goodwill, but you'll find her peevish.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No matter, sir, for that, I would not have her easily, I would sweat for her, I'll warrant, I'll make her love me.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Look you can you read, I made a ditty to send to my mistress, and my musician that I keep in my house, to teach my daughter, hath set it to a very good air, he tells me: you shall hear and judge of it, I hear him tuning his instrument.

lg.l: God of war to Cupid yield,
He is master of the field,
He with arrow hits the heart,
Thou with lance the worser part.
Cupid greater is then Jove,
Since he wounded was with love,
Nay, in power by much odds
He excels the other gods.
Love transformed Jove to a swan,
Made Ulysses a mad man,
But Rufaldo it does make
Young for his Selina's sake.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: How do you relish it, ha?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I troth the ditty is as pretty an air as ere I saw, 'tis divided into three regions too, I warrant you, can make ballads easily.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: O fie, they are barbarous and ignoble, that's beggarly.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: But for all that, I have read good stuff sometimes, especially in your fighting ballads, when cannons are roaring, and bullets are flying, etc.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Fie, a whipping post, tinkerly stuff; how did you like the air?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: As sweet an air as a man would wish to live in, but 'tis somewhat backward.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: O music, the life of the soul.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I should have learned music once too, but my master had so many crochets, I could ne'er away with it: but where is your daughter, sir? there is no music without her, she is the best instrument to play upon.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: And you shall have her between your legs presently.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I had as lief be betwixt hers, for all that.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Hilaria, where is this girl? I'll fetch her to you, and leave her with you, for I have a love of mine own, to whom I mean in person to present this ditty, I'll fetch her.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I do not see what fault she can find with me, and if I had some good word to come over her: but I must help it out and need be, with swearing; but here she is.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Still Antonio with you? you are a foolish girl: do I take care to provide a husband for you? and will you cast away yourself upon a prodigal? but that I would not discontent his sister, whom I hope to make my wife, I would forbid him my house; therefore be wise, and take heed of him, he's giddy-headed, and loose-bodied. The bee may buzz, but he will leave a sting: plant your love there: upon my blessing, he has many lordships.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Pray heaven he have good manners.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I have set open the gate of opportunity; Cupid speed us both.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Let me alone to enter my man, now the point is open: hum, stay, there's a man in her tables more than I looked for: foot, he kisses her, I'll call Rufaldo back, he's out of sight, it were but a cowardly trick, for me to runaway.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Be buzzard now, the sting of conscience eat up his gut, fry his suet, and leave him at his death not able to weigh down a pound of candle.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: He talks of svet, I do melt already.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Look, do you see that man of clothes? upon my father's blessing he must be my husband. What will you do?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fight with him, his clothes are too big for him, I'll beat him till he swell to 'em.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: No, as you love me, do not strike him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I will set a good face whatsoever come. Hilaria, how does my love, come kiss: why so: this comes of valour, we fall to, and he falls off, he's some coward, I hope, and how dost Hilaria? 'tis an age since I saw thee: what springals is that? ha.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: One that desires to be of your acquaintance, sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: My acquaintance, who is he? none but knights, and knights fellows, are of my acquaintance, I scorn gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p: But for my sake, pray be acquainted with him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Thou shalt do much with me, sir, I am content for her sake whom I love, to be acquainted with you, wilt borrow any money? for so do all that begin their acquaintance with me, 'tis the fashion, he is a coward, is he not? here: nay, and you scorn my money, I scorn your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Pray for my sake.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why, he will borrow no money of me, I had never such a trick put upon me, since I knew what acquaintance was: I'm sure there have been forty acquainted with me, since I came to town, and not one had not so little breeding, to let me ask 'em the question, we could no sooner shake hands, but the other was in my pocket: it may be 'tis his modesty. Sir, this is my love Hilaria, and if you will not borrow money of me, by this hand, there lies my sword, he is a coward.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It appears.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Hilaria is my mistress, and if any man dare be so venturous, as to blast her reputation with a foul breath, he shall breathe his last.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: 'Tis very sure, he shall not be immortal.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Or if you shall offer in my presence to defile her lip, or touch her hand, or kiss but the nether part of her vesture, you had better kiss her in another place; nay do but blow on her.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You forget yourself, this is my friend.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Or wink at her, or speak to her, or make signs, or think on her to my face, and you had better keep your thoughts to yourself: now to conclude, and if you be aggrieved, my name is Bubulcus, and you lie.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And you lie there ath' ground: why should not I knock his brains out with his own hilts, or stake him to the ground, like a man that had hanged himself? Sirrah clothes, rat of Nilus' fiction, monster, golden calf, o, I would kick thee till thou hast no more brains, than thy cousin woodcock: I will not dishonour myself to kill thee, half a dozen kicks will be as good as a house of correction, out you monkey.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: O, that I could run thee thorough body and soul, I will challenge thee, a pox on your toes, would I had the paring of your nails, were you dumb so long for this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hence.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Who looked for you? when will you be here again? look for a challenge, the time may come, when I will beat thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Has thy father left a multitude of men, to make choice of this piece of folly to be thy husband? o, the blindness of a covetous wretched father, that is led only by the ears, and in love with sounds! Nature had done well to have thrust him into the world without an eye, that like a mole is so affected to base earth, and there means to dig for paradise: but come, Hilaria. Fathers their children, and themselves abuse, that wealth a husband for their daughter choose.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I did not think, Rufaldo, pardon me,
You could have so prevailed, but if she can
Plant her affection on ye, I'll not be
Backward to call you son.

sp.speaker: Seli.
sp.l: He does appear
With all the charms of love upon his eye,
and not rough drawn, but polished, he assumes
A power 'bove all resistance.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: An old man's darling, is a petty Queen
Above all her desires.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Nay, she shall want nothing my wealth can purchase,
Oh my sweet Selina.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Rufaldo, with your patience, I would have
A word or two in private, you need not
Prejudicate me.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Selina, thou knowest I am thy father.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: My duty, sir, shall speak it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And you know whom you have rejected.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Young Infortunio.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And you know what man he is, with whom
You mean to tie that knot, nothing but
Death is able to undo.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Rufaldo, sir, an old man.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O Selina, Felice thy poor sister thou recall'st
To sad remembrance, but heaven alas
Knows only where she is.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sir, I have often heard you talk of her,
But never knew that sister well.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Thou with thy uncle's tenderness wast kept
Always ith' country, not until her loss
At home with me, her fate taught me to give
A liberty to thee, her I restrained
Poor wench in love with Gasparo, till betwixt
Obedience to a father, and the love
To him, she left us both, father and friend,
Now to avoid the like affliction,
I vowed thy freedom, and thou seest I do
Not encounter thy affection with the bonds
A father might enforce upon his child.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I humbly thank you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: But yet Selina,
take heed, be not too rash, I have observed
You want no common judgement, oh do not
Precipitate thyself into a sorrow,
Shall waste thee with repentance, let me tell you,
There is a method, when your passion's young
To keep it in obedience: you love Rufaldo,
Art thou not young? How will the rose agree
With a dead hyacinth? or the honey woodbine,
Circling a withered briar?
You can apply, can you submit your body
To bed with ice and snow, your blood to mingle?
Would you be deafed with coughing, teach your eye
How to be rheumatic? Breathes he not out
His body in diseases, and like dust
Falling all into pieces, as if nature
Would make him his old grave: I say too much.
O what are all the riches of the world,
To an oppressed mind? which then must be
Fed with despair of change, or will gold
Buy off th' imprisonment? nay, will it not
Compose the chains, that bind you to endure it?
Well I have said enough, keep still your freedom,
And lose it where you will, you shall not blame
Me for your fate, nor grieve me with your shame.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Dear father, low as earth I tender you
The duty of a daughter, I have heard you
Not with a careless ear, that liberty
You have bestowed on me, for which I owe
All that I am, doth make me confident
You will not be offended, if I tell you
My love is virtuous, were it otherwise,
I should elect as you premonish youth,
And prodigal blood: and father, I think here
I show myself your daughter, nor am I
Without good precedent too: how many fine
Young noble ladies, in this fairy I'll,
have matched with reverend age? and live as they
Were born from nature's purity, free from stain
Of sensual imputation, by their loves,
Deriving heavenly honours to themselves
'Bove merit of equality.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: No more, heaven's blessing and mine
Light on thee, shalt have Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I would not leave Rufaldo for a world
Of rash untemperate youth, believe it sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Rufaldo, heard you that? she says she would not
Leave you for a world of other men.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Nor I for thousand worlds forsake my love.
Come seal it with a kiss, another, another, another.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: As close as cockles.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: O, that we were married! 'tis death to stay the
Ceremonies, would we were a-bed together.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Twere time I see we were at conference,
To confirm all things for the marriage,
You being agreed, I think we shall not differ
In other circumstance, and 'twere sin to let
That keep your joys asunder by delay:
Please you we'll have some treaties.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Most willingly, oh my bird, my chick, my dove,
My America, my new-found world, I shall shortly
Run back into one and twenty again.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: With what agility he moves himself,
As he were made of air? let weakness tax
Our inequality, I have a mind
Can easily contemn what the world's malice
Out of its own first guiltiness can throw
Upon our loves, 't shall be enough for me
Thus to convince the world of so much baseness,
Lodged in luxurious thoughts, by my chaste thoughts.
Rufaldo, thou art mine, all time, methinks
Is slow, till we be actually possessed
of mutual enjoying. Stay, who's this
sp.stage: Enter Lenkin, and his page Locarello.
sp.l: The Welshman that delivers his affection
At second hand to me.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Look you pages, where our sweethearts and pigsnies be, and her could tell what to say to her now, know her heart very well, but pogs upon her, cannot all her knowledge speak rhetorics, and oratories, and fine words to her? look you know better to fight, and cut doublets with her Welsh glaves, mark you.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Sir will you lose this opportunity, you'll curse yourself in Welsh, two or three days together for't.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Gentlewoman, if her knaw not her name, was Jenkin, born in Wales, came of big houses, and Prittish bloods was have great hills and mountains all her own, when was get 'em again, any was her cousin's, and our countryman was never conquered, but always have the victories pravely, have her arms and scutcheons, to know that say you, was give in her crests great deal of monsters, and dragons, kill 'em with their hooks very valiantly, as any sentelman in the whole world: pray you now was please you place her affections and goodwills upon her, in ways of makemoney, mark you teale plainly, Lenkin was love her very honestly, else pox upon her, and her will fight in her cause, and quarrels, long as have any blood in her bellies and backs too, mark you.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sir, I am bound to you for the affection
You cast on me, 'tis far above my merit.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Merits say you? all merits are all banished our countries and nations, you know dat: pray you was her love Lenkin?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Love you, sir? I know not
How to be so inhumane, not to love you,
Your parts deserve a nobler object, I am not
Worthy so much opinion of your love,
But wherein I may do you service sir,
you shall command Selina.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Shall her, was make her means and satisfactions warrant her, or say Senkin was sentleman of Wales, say you now pages, was have her matrimonies and wedlocks very fast, look you, and when was get her awse her cousins, was make joys and gratulation for her good fortunes upon her Welsh harps, know you dat very well pages? her fear her shall be knighted one days, and have great cumulations of urships, honours, and dignities too, a great while ago.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: And great castles ith' air.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Was give all our lands, and craggy tenements in Wales away to our cousin up John, and live herself here upon very good fashions, with our moneys and mighty riches, when her can get 'em.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: How now, whither so fast, man? thou mayst get to hell by night, and thou goest but an alderman's pace.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: By cat's blood, her will go to the devil and her list, what is that to her?

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Cry you mercy, your name is master Lenkin.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: And what have her to say to master Lenkin? Lenkin is as good names as her own, pray you was good sentle man as herself, know very well, say you now?

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Good-bye, sir.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Boys, does her call her boys? hark you her? her name is Lenkin, her be no boys, no shildren.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: I will not be used so.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Her shall be used worse, and her call Lenkin boys, was knock as tall a man as herself, an Welsh blood be up, look you.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Can she love Rufaldo? 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Piple pables, 'tis very possible.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: His body has more diseases than an hospital, an hunger-starved rascal.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Rascals? sheshu! was never such names and appellations put upon her, all her days, becar her will make you eat up all her words and ignominies, or her plade shall make holes in your bellies diggon.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: A very puff, a weak cannibal.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Hey, puff, and cannibals, if the devil be in your mouths, her will pick your teeths with her Welsh plade, and pay you for all your puffs, and cannibals, warrant her.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: But 'tis her fault, alone impudent woman.
O, may you like Narcissus perish by
Your face, the fall of others, or unpitied
Of heaven and earth, die loathsome! I could curse.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.l: Her can curse, and swear too, look you now.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Pardon divinest sex, passions do force
My reason from me, I do submit,
Crave pardon, as your creature.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Nay, and her crave pardons, and make submissions, Lenkin was put up all her angers and indignations, farewell.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: O, Selina!
Thou art too much an adamant
To draw my soul unto thee, either be
Softer, or less attractive: but Rufaldo,
'Tis depth of witchcraft, o, I could be mad,
Beyond all patience mad, it is some malice
Hath laid this poison on her.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Here's Infortunio. Alas, poor gentleman, little does he think what black and white is here, a bitter handful of commendations to him, my young mistress is mad of the old coxcomb, and will marry him almost without asking, I cannot tell but if she do not cuckold him, and make him cry corns on his toes ere he die, he has fool's fortune, for a wise man would be out of hope to avoid it, he spies me.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Whither running, Gorgon?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Not out of my wit, sir, I have a letter from my young mistress Selina, must in all haste have cleanly conveyance to old Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Let me but see the directions. To my beloved friend master Rufaldo: 'tis a lie, she was mistaken, it was I should owe this appellation, I'll not believe the superscription, 'tis a painted face, I'd see the heart on't.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: I hope, sir, you will not throw open the sheet, and discover my mistress secrets? How he stares!

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: If you love me, and wish me constant, be your own friend, and let our marriage day begin with the next morning: thine, mine. O Selina, she's mad. All womankind is mad; and I am mad: whom shall I rend in pieces for my wrongs, and as with atoms fill this poisoned air, Rufaldo? Stay, is not she a creature rational? o no, there is no spark of nature in her, all is sunk, lost for ever: stay, stay, see.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: He has made a tailor's bill on't, torn't apieces ere it be discharged: what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: This is Medea's brother torn in pieces,
And this the way where she with Jason flies,
Tom Colchos, come not near 'em, see, look,
That's an arm rent off.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: This?

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: And the hand beckons us
To cry out murder.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: I'll but hold it by the hand.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: That's a leg o'th boy.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: This sir, a leg, it shall go with me then.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: There, there 'tis, head and yellow curled locks,
His eyes are full of tears, now they do stare,
To see where all his other members lie.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: So I have all his quarters, I'll presently, sir, get poles for 'em, and hang 'em upon the gates in their postures for you.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: But she and Jason are both slipped, and Argos is
sailing home to Greece, see how the waves
Do toss the vessel, and the winds conspire
To dash it 'gainst a rock, it rides upon
A watery mountain, and is hid in clouds,
It cannot stay there, now, now, it tumbles,
Three fathom beneath hell, let 'em go,
Here comes the father of Medea now,
Calling in vain unto the gods, and spies
His son's limbs thrown about, in stead of flowers,
To his daughter's nuptials he does take 'em up,
He knows the face, and now he tears his hair,
And raves, and cries Medea, poor old man,
Command a funeral pile for thy young child,
And lay the pretty limbs on, from whose ashes
Shalt have another son i'th shape of phoenix.
Shall I? excellent! Prepare a fire
All of sweet wood for my sweet boy, a fire, a fire.

div.head: Actus tertius, scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p:
'Tis now early day: fie, what a long night hath this been? the sun went drunk to bed the last night, and could not see to rise this morning: I could hardly wink, I am sure, love kept me waking, and the expectation of this my wedding day did so caper in my brains, I thought of nothing but dancing the shaking of the sheets with my sweetheart. It is certain, I am young everybody now tells me, so it did appear by Selina's consenting so soon to love, for when I had but broke the ice of my affection, she fell over head and ears in love with me; was ever man so happy as I am? I do feel, I do feel my years fall off, as the rain from a man that comes dropping in, I do feel myself every day grow younger and younger still: let me see, an
hundred years hence, if I live to 't, I shall be new out of my teens, and running into years of discretion again: well, I will now to master Cornelio's, and bid 'em good morrow with a noise of musicians, and to see the very talking of music, how my heart leaps and dances, at my wedding already! I have bespoke the parson to marry us, and have promised a double fee for expedition. O now I am so proud of my joy, my feet do not know what ground they stand on.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Jenkin has risen very early this mornings, and been in studies and contemplations, to make ditties and verses upon her mistress beauties and pulchritudes, but the devil's sure in these poetries, they call it furies and raptures, look you, but Jenkin's pate is almost mad, and yet her cannot all her inventions meet with these furies and raptures.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Thus far I have passed without discovery: the morning is auspicious to my flight. Selina, what an alteration hath a day made in thee, that to prevent thy so desired marriage, thou art thus lost in a masculine habit, and dost fly him? thou didst so much love aged Rufaldo, in what a lethargy wert thou fallen, Selina?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Jocarello, does her not name Selina? 'tis no very good manners to make interruptions, her will hear more, look you.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Whither had reason so withdrawn itself?
I could not make distinction of a man,
From such a heap of age, aches and rheum:
Sure I was mad, and doth increase my fury,
To think with what a violence I ran
To embrace such rottenness. O, my guilty soul
Doth feel the punishment of the injury
I did to Infortunio of late,
of whom as I despair, so shall the world,
Ever to know again hapless Selina.
This is the morn the sacred rites should tie
Me to Rufaldo, ripe in expectation,
But like Ixion he shall grasp a cloud,
My empty clothes at home, Selina thus
Is turned a shepherd, and will try her fortune;
Hard by the shepherds have their shady dwellings,
There let Selina end her hapless days,
Father and all farewell. Thus as Felice
My other sister, I'll wear out my life,
Far from your knowledge: sacred love commands
Revenge and justice for my cruelty,
And reason now awaked shall lead me to it,
Thus I am safe, I go to find out that,
Will meet me everywhere , a just sad fate.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Pages, have her seen treames and apparitions: hark you, was Selina turned shepherdess, pray you?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Either we dream, or this was Selina, your mistress, that is turned into breeches, and become a shepherd; the case is altered.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: What a devil is in the matters and businesses, pray you? cases never was known such cases and alterations in all her life, woman's never wear preeches in Wales, 'tis not possible, we are all in treames and visions, very treames and visions.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Sure we are all awaked, sir, and it was Selina, did she not say she would obscure herself from her father's knowledge, and live among the shepherd's hard by?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: It may be, but it is very impossible.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I am amazed, when was she seen?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not today, sir, I have searched her chamber, and almost turned it out ath' window, but no Selina.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: It is very strange, is not your man Gorgon come back?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: What should this mean, it is a strange absence, ath' wedding day too.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: That angers me most, sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: My heart misgives me, some fatal accident upon my life, is happened to her.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Hast thou happy news?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I have travelled all the town o'er, and can meet no intelligence of her.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Be dumb, night-raven, she's lost, she's lost,
The fates sure make conspiracy to take
My daughters from me: one I lost because
I would not give her, and I have repented
Full justice for it, and am I so unhappy
To lose Selina too? but I'll not sleep,
Until I find her either alive or dead.
Rufaldo, you have interest in this sorrow,
Join in the inquisition. O my girl Selina.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Have I been young for this? if I find her not, I will run, I will run, I will run mad, mad.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No more, I know where her clothes be: if it take, applaud my invention: I have cozened my own father before now, and I will try new conclusions, but I must have thy assistance and secrecy: if my sister have a conceit of mirth to put upon us, I may chance put her to prove herself Selina, or remove her with a habeas corpus.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p:
Iocarello's, all is true, Selina is gone in shepherd's vestments to the woods and forests, but her will make travels and ambulations after her: never was sentilman ith' hole world love as Jenkin now, to make journeys and peregrinations for a woman's, look you: but if her find her, as know her very well, her will there make all sure works and performances, warrant you pages, here is moneys,
pray you make provisions of breads and victuals too, know uds are very bare places, and Shenkin was always have cud stomachs and appetites, look you, pray you, do, pray you, do.

div.stage: Complement-schoole. Enter Gasparo habited punctually, master of the school, and Gorgon his usher

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Be the hangings up, Curculio, and all the chairs and stools put into method? the day is old, methinks , time runs fast, methinks , upon the minute, brings my disciples. Do my bills of compliment still relish, Curculio, do they please the palate, ha?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: My most ingenious and noble Criticotaster, bravely bills, pills you should say, not faced, but lined, with gold they swallow 'em greedily, and still flock to 'em, and conglomerate my son and heir of the Muses: a proclamation is as quiet as the poor man's box, no man looks after it, not a ballad-monger has any audience: but happy is the man that rides first post to your papers and cries admirable: your old men look upon 'em with their spectacles, as they would eye an obligation within a minute of forfeiture.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Thou hast eaten up the furies already, and speakest all buskins, but close walk in the clouds, yet I have not heard of any mountebank of wit durst ever attempt to set up shop ath' trade yet: but whist, usher, take your place.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Foot, 'tis Bubulcus.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: This is the compliment-school.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Three cuts and a half, heigh. I give you, sir, generous salutation, and wish a fair morn descend upon you: thrice noble spirit, welcome, does your worship desire to be sprinkled with the drops of Helicon, to gather the pippins of Parnassus, and have your forehead filleted with Apollinean bays, or laurel?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Troth, sir, I do not know how to construe what you say, although I know it be Latin, sir: the cause of my coming to you, is to let you understand, that here is a compliment-school, and I have great desire to be taught some of your fegaries, and brave words, I do mean to pay for't soundly too, sir: I thank my stars, as they say, I have ready money about me.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: You shall be verberated, and reverberated, my exact piece of stolidity: please you draw near, there is the star of eloquence, under whom I am an hypodidascal, in English, his usher.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: A gentleman usher at least.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Approach without fear: here is a pupil, sir, desires to suck the honey of your eloquence, he is a gentleman in folio.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Your accession is grateful, my most gentile lump of insipience: what compliment doth arride the palate of your generosity?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What says he pray, in English?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: He asks what kind of verbosity you would be practised in? because I perceive you are raw, I will descend to your capacity, he asks what compliment you would learn?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why look you, sir, I would have two kinds of compliments: for, sir, I am in love, and I am in hate.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: How? in love, and hate too?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Yes, I am in love with a wench, and would have a delicate speech for her, and I am in hate with a gentleman, a young animal, and I would kill him now without danger of the law: to tell you true, he did abuse me in the presence of my sweetheart, and did (Saving this good company) kiss my backside.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
But it was with his foot, sir: now in regard I have not the heart to kill him with my sword, I would cut him in pieces, and murder him with mouth-guns: look
you, sir, here's money, please yourself: but I pray you give me a powdering speech, for I would blow him up: I beseech you, if ever you put gall into your ink, make it a bitter speech.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Sir, I will draw you a sublime speech shall conjure him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Pray do, for he has a great spirit in him.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Usher, in the mean time entertain him with some copy of amorous compliment.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: There is an usher's fee belongs to my place.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Here's gold for your fee, I received it for good fee simple, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Simple, I am sure: so, sir, look you, I should teach
You to make a leg first, but these postures anon.
Resplendent mistress, for thy face doth far
Excel all other, like a blazing star
We mortals wonder at, vouchsafe to cast
Out of those sparkling diamond eyes thou hast,
A sacred influence on thy vowed creature,
That is confounded with thy form and feature.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Admirable!

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Goddess of Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Stay, I do not like that word cypress, for she'll think I mean to make hatbands on her, cannot you call her taffeta goddess, or if you go to stuff, cloth a gold were richer.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: O, there's a conceit, Cyprus is the emblem of morning, and here by Cyprus you declare how much you pine and mourn after her, sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Very good, pray you go on.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Goddess of Cyprus, Venus is a slut.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Stay, who do I call slut now? the goddess of Cyprus, Venus, or my love?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: You do tell the goddess, that Venus is a slut.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I do so.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: For thou art Venus fair, and she is not.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How is she Venus' fair, when then I call her slut to her face?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: No, sir, your love is Venus fair, and she is not:
That makes plain the other, that she is a slut.
O that I were a flea upon thy lip,
There would I suck for ever, and not skip.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Suck?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: That is, you would not bite her by the lip.
Or if thou thinkst I there too high am placed,
I'll be content to suck below thy waste.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Which side she please.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Thy foot I'd willing kiss, but that I know,
Thou wouldst not have thy servant stoop so low.
She will give you leave to kiss higher.
O speak thou, wilt be mine? and I will be
The truest worm e'er trod on shoe to thee.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Worm?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: By worm you do insinuate and wriggle yourself into your affection, and she by shoe will conceive your desire the length of her foot: how do you like it, sir?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I would not for forty pounds but I had come to compliment: why, I shall be able in a small time to put down a reasonable gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: O, any ordinary lady, you must get it without book. Now to make your legs.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I have two made to my hands.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: O, by no means, your legs are made to your feet.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Beauty and graces dwell upon the face
Of my disciple Delia.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Muses inspire you: what, at study?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Negotiating a little with the Muses.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: See me salute her.
As many happinesses wait on Delia,
As beams shoot from the sun this pleasant morn.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: As many thanks requite you, as that sun
Is old in minutes since the day begun.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What's she, Curculio?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Her mistress's best movable, a chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: She is an early riser: at school so soon?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: She is an early riser, and yet sometime as soon down as up, she cannot be quiet for the serving-men, 'tis her hour between eight o'clock and her mistress rising, to come to discipline.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: 'Tis a pretty smug wench, is her name Delia? she has a pretty name too.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: O, sir, all her credit is in her good name: it was Diana's the goddess of chastity, and therefore when she marries, she may cuckold her husband by a privilege, for Diana gave horns to Actaeon.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Where's master Criticotaster?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir, my master has sent you a little gold, he desires you send him the speech he should speak at sessions in the country, he's now riding down.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Sir Valentine Wantbraine, that has never a clerk?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: The same, sir.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Newly put into commission for the peace, being puisne, it falls to him to give the charge. I have drawn it, let me see in comitatu, etc. here, read it, Curculio, he may the better instruct his master, a touch, a touch.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p:
Good men of the jury for this session, I will not implicate you with ambages and circumstances, I am unwilling to confound your little wits with affected divisions of my narration, into quis, quid, quomodo, and quandoes: I will neither utter by gross, nor part my speech into a dozen of long points, knotted often in the middle, and untagged in the end; you are to present malefactors, whereof you are the chief — reformers, and seeing you stand
ready for your charge, I will give fire to this great piece of service, and send you all off with a powder, that in any case we may go to dinner betimes, etc.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: So, 'tis enough: bear my respects to your master, tell him 'tis a speech will do him credit, bid him learn it perfectly without book.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: And do you hear, if he chance to be at a nonplus, he may help himself with his beard and handkercher, or it will be a good posture for his hand now and then to be fumbling with his bandstrings. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Mistress Medulla, the sun of honour shine upon your hopes, till it sublime you to a ladyship: I will attend you presently.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Sirrah, bid your fellow make ready the caroche, and attend me here about an hour hence, I will ride home.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What gentlewoman is that?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: An old country gentlewoman, that hath buried her husband lately, and comes up to be a lady, for she swears she will not marry any more gentlemen: she is fallen out with a justice of peace's wife in the country, and she will have a knight, though she pay for his horse-hire, to spite her neighbours.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: A word with you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Your friend and master Bubulcus. Ha you done, sir?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: The Cupidinaean fires burn in my breast,
And like the oven Aetna, I am full
Of squibs and crackers.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: This will powder him.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p:
Lady, wounded by your beauty, I will acknowledge mercy if you kill me not, yet rather murder me, then vulnerate still your creature, unless you mean to medicine where you have hurt, and I implore no better remedy than I may derive from the instrument wherewith you pierced me, like Achilles' spear, your eye having shot
lightning into my breast, hath power with a smile to fetch out the consuming fire, and yet leave my heart inflamed.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Sir, although where I am not guilty of offence, I might deny justly, to descend to a satisfaction: yet rather than I would be counted a murderer, I would study to preserve so sweet a model as yourself; and since you desire my eye which inflamed you, should with the virtue of a gracious smile make you happy in your fire, it shall shine as you would have it, and disclaim that beam shall shine upon another object.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: So, very well, this is your cunning lesson.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Some strangers, Curoutio.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Sir, the country comes in upon us.

div.stage: Enter an Old-man with his son.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Is not here a compliment-school?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: A school of generous education, sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: I have brought my son to be a scholar, I do mean to make him a courtier, I have an offer of five or six offices for my money, and I would have him first taught to speak.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: He is a great child, cannot he speak yet?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: In what kind of compliment, please you, venerable sir, to be edoctrinated? But we will withdraw.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come, for another lesson, my brave Mars,
Now I am fit to quarrel with the stars,
And catch at Jove.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Orlando Furioso.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: By the blood-stained falchion of Mavors I will carbonado thee, keep off, or in my fury I will cut thee into atoms, and blow thee about the world.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: I hope he does but compliment.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will out-labour jove-born Hercules,
And in a greater fury ransack hell:
Tear from the sisters their contorted curls,
And wrack the destinies on Ixion's wheel,
Brain Proserpine with Sisyphus' rolling stone,
And in a brazen cauldron choked with lead,
Boil Minos, Aeacus, and Radamanth,
Throw Pluto headlong into moorish fens,
And sooty regions.
Dam up Cocytus with tormented soul,
And batter down the brazen gates of hell,
Make the infernal three-chapped band-dog roar.
Cram Tantalus with apples, lash the fiends
With whips of snakes, and poisoned scorpions,
Snatch chained Prometheus from the vulture's maw,
And feed him with her liver, make old Charon
Waft back again the souls, or buffet him
With his own oars to death.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: So, so, 'tis well, you shall take forth a new lesson, sit down and breathe.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: 'Twas a devilish good speech.

div.stage: Enter a justice of peace's clerk, Ingeniolo.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: O, why did nature make thee fair and cruel?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: What spruce fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: He is an hundred and fifty pounds a yard in potentia, a yeoman's son, and justice of peace's clerk, he is in love with a farmer's daughter, and thus he speaks his passion in blank verse.

sp.speaker: Inge.
sp.l: Thou art some goddess, that to amaze the earth
With thy celestial presence, hath put on
The habit of a mortal, gods sometimes
Would visit country houses, and guild o'er
A sublunary habitation
With glory of their presence, and make heaven
Descend into an hermitage: sure thy father
was Maia's son, disguised in shepherd's weeds,
And thou dost come from Jove, no marvel than
We swains do wonder at thee, and adore,
Venus herself the Queen of Cithaeron,
When she is riding through the milky way,
Drawn with white doves, is but a blouse, and must,
When thou appearest, leave her bird-drawn coach,
And give the reins to thee, and trudge afoot
Along the heavenly plains, paved with stars,
In duty of thy excellence, while the gods
Looking amazed from their crystal windows,
Wonder what new-come deity doth call
Them to thy adoration.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: O, heavenly farmer's daughter!

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: I'll call him in; Ingeniolo!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Your servant, sir. Lady, I kiss your hand, and reverence the antiquity of your vestment, Delia. Fortune let fall her riches on thy head, that thou mayst fill thy apron. I am your humble observicer, and wish you all cumulations of prosperity.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Sir, I desire to suck below your waste.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I do evaculate myself to be your shadows, my generous condisciples.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: This is scholarlike.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: He's one of the head form, I warrant.

div.stage: Enter Gasparo, the old man and his son.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Sir, I receive your son, and will wind up his ingeny, fear it not, but first he must be under my usher, who must teach him the postures of his body, how to make legs and cringes, and then he shall be advanced to a higher class. Curculio, lick him with your method into some proportion, take off the roughness of his behaviour, and then give him the principles of salutation.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: La you there, boy, he will teach you the principles of saltation. Well, good-morrow, sir, I'll leave my jewel.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Your jewel may have the grace to be hanged one day.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Bless you sentlemen all, and your studies and contemplations: is here a school of compliments, pray you?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: A place of generous breeding.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Generous preeding, hark you, her name was Jenkin, a good sentleman, 'tis known, her take no pleasures and delectations in urds and phrases of rhetorics; Welsemen have all hearts and fidelities, mark you, her was going along pout create business, but casting her eyes and visions upon your pills and significations of your skills and professions, look you, her come in, to see the fashions and manners of your exercises, and yet if your urships has any madrigals and pastoral canticles, look you, for in truths and verities was going now to the uds and forests, and mean to turn shepherds goddillings, her will give you good payments of all your inventions, and muses, pray you now.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Amorous pastorals? I can furnish you, venerable sir.

lg.l: Turn, Amarillis, to thy swain,
Thy Damon calls thee back again,
Here is a pretty arbour by,
Where Apollo cannot pry,
Here let's sit, and while I play
Sing to my pipe a roundelay.

sp.p: How like you it, sir?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Roundelays very good, here is moneys and considerations, look you.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: We acknowledge your bounty, my tenth-worthy.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p:
So mistress, I have trespassed on your patience, now I will take occasion by the forelock. You can say your lecture: have you your handkercher ready, that when a suitor comes, you may put him off with wiping your eyes, as if tears stood in 'em ever since your husband was buried; well, suppose I have had access to your chamber, I begin,
lady, think it not strange, if love which is active in my bosom, force me to turn petitioner, that I may be reckoned amongst your servants; all my ambition, sweetest, is to be made happy in your affection, which I will study to deserve in my utmost possibilities.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Alas, alas, I had a husband.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Very well counterfeited, nay weep not, those eyes were made to shine, not waste with dew: if it be for the remembrance of him you have lost, recover him again, by placing your good opinion on a man shall sweat to do you services.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: It doth not, sir, become our modesty
To talk of love so soon, you will renew
My passion for his loss, and draw down tears
Afresh upon his hearse: you do not well
To oppress a widow thus, I pray, sir, leave me,
At least I will enjoin you, if you stay,
To speak no more of love, it is unwelcome.
What, am I perfect?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: So 'twas very well, at the next lesson you shall learn to be more cunning.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Will't please you hear the novice?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Good boy, speak out.

sp.speaker: Off
sp.p: God save you, sir, felicities be accumulated upon you, sir, I thank you generous sir, you oblige me to be your servant, sir, in all my — p — oh — s — possibility, sir, I honour your remembrance, sir, and shall be proud to do you my observance, sir, most noble sir.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Very hopeful now: a repetition all together, the more, the merrier.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: What, at barleybreak? which couple are in hell? are not you Helen, whose insatiate lust ruined fair Illium? and you sir Paris with a golden nose? hark you, Rufaldo is married to Selina.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Who? that's my father in law.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: How, your father? look, he has cloven feet, I am glad I have found you, what are you in hell for?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Insinuate to 'em all for their own safeties, he's desperate mad, bid none stir hence.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Hey, how came you all thus damned?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.l: Damned, who's damned? is Jenkin damned?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: I beseech you, sir, to maintain the credit of my school, I shall be undone else, humour him a little.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Will you have her be damned? when hear you pray a Welshman was damned? of all things in the urld, her cannot abide to be damned.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: See if you can roar him away.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Keep off, I am Hercules, son of Alcmena,
Compressed by Jove, I'll carbonado thee.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: How, art thou Hercules?
Lie there, usurper of Alcides' name,
Bold centaur: so he's dead, by this I prove
I am Jove born.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Well, for your credits and reputations, her care not to be damned for companies and fellowships, look you, has he knocked him down? would he had knocked Jenkin down.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Now, on with your relations, and tell me all the storeys of your fortunes.
sp.l: 'Tis I am Hercules, sent to free you all.
What are you damned for? In this club behold
All your releasements. What are you?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: Stand in order and be damned.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: I am the conscience of an usurer,
Who have been damned these two and twenty years,
For lending money gratis.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: How, a usurer? why didst not
Corrupt the devil to fetch thy soul away?
He'll take a bribe for lending money gratis.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Yes, sir, for thanks: I took no interest,
for at the lending of each hundred pound ▪
They brought my home some twenty or thirty thanks,
Indeed 'twas paid in gold.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: O golden thanks I well, go to, I'll release you,
Upon condition you shall build an hospital,
And die a beggar. What are you?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: The soul of a watchman.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: How came you damned? could not you watch the devil?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: He took me napping on midsummer Eve, and I never dream 't on him.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Your wife had given you opium over night.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No sir, I had watched three nights before, and because I would not wink at two or three drunkards as they went reeling home at twelve o'clock at night, the devil owed me a spite.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Well, you shall be prentice to an alchemist, and watch his still's night, by night, not sleep till he get the philosophers-stone. What are you?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Sir, I am a chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: What are you damned for?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Not for revealing my mistress secrets, for I kept them better than mine own, but keeping my maidenhead till it was stale, I am condemned to lead apes in hell.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Alas, poor wench, upon condition you will be wise hereafter, and not refuse gentlemen's proffers, learn pride every day, and painting, bestow a courtesy now and then upon the apparitor to keep counsel, I release you, take your apes, and monkeys away with you, and bestow them on gentlewomen, and ladies, that want playfellows. What are you?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I am an undersheriff, sir, damned because I told the debtors, writs were out against 'em, brought 'em to composition without arrests, favoured poor men for a whole year together, was very good in my office, gave up a just account at the years end, and broke.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: O, miracle! an honest man! thou shalt be churchwarden to a parish, draw the 〈◊〉, and keep the poor men's box for seven years together, 'tis pity, but thou the eldest have fifty writer, to propagate honest generation. What are you?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: A justice's wife ith' the country, sir.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: And who drew your 〈◊〉 hither? what are you damned for?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: For refusing satin gowns, and velvet petticoats, turning back capons at Christina's, and sessions times, and making much of one of my husband's servants, merely for his honesty and good service towards me.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: 'Tis injustice, you shall bury your husband quickly, wear some blacks a while for fashion's sake, and within a month be married to his clerk, unless you will be divided among the serving-men. What are you?

sp.speaker: Old man's son.
sp.p: A younger brother, sir, born at the latter end of the week, and wane of the moon, put into the world to seek my own fortune, got a great estate of wealth by gaming and wenching, and so purchased unhappily this state of damnation you see me in.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Came you in't by purchase? than you do not claim it by yours father's interest as an heir: well, I will ease you of the estate, because it is litigious, and you shall make presently a bargain and sale of it to a scrivener, that shall buy it of you, and pay you both his ears down upon the nail for it. What are you?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I am a horse-courser.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: And couldst not thou outride the devil?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
I had not the grace to mend my pace, I was an honest horse-courser, and suffered every fool to ride me, I knew not what belonged to horseplay, let the world kick at me, I never winced, all that I am damned for, is, that desiring to thrive in the world, and to have good-luck to horseflesh, I ambled to the bed of a parson's wife that was coltish once, and gave her husband a horse for't in
good fashion, he never gave me godamercy for't, indeed it proved afterwards to have the yellows.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: There was some colour for't: well, since your occupation is foundered, you shall trot every day afoot, and walk a knave in the horse-fair. What are you?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Her have no mind at all to be damned, becar her will fight with her and kill all the devils in hell: diggon.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, here's more ado to get one Welshman damned, than a whole nation. Sir, 'tis but in jest.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: In jests, is it in jests? well, look you, her will be contented to be damned in jests and merriments for you.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: You will tell me what you are damned for?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: And her be so hot, was get somebody's else to be damned for Jenkin, her will tell her in patiences, look you, her was damned for her valour, and ridding the urld of monsters, look you, dragons with seven heads, and serpents with tails a mile long, pray you.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: O, let me embrace thee, worthy in my arms, I'll charm the destinies for their bold attempt, for cutting off thy thread, thou shalt cut their throats, and be installed lord in Elysium, o, let me hug thee, Owen Glendower.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Owen Glendower was her cousin, pray you.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Go your ways all: stay, take hence Prometheus and bury him, if you come into hell again, there's no releasement.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: So, farewell sentlemen, now her mean to make travels and peregrinations, to the uds and plains, look you, very fast. Good speed to all.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: We thank thee jovial Hercules.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Live long thou King of hell. So, so, well done of all sides, here our school breaks up, I might have run mad like, had I not taken off the edge of melancholy. Thus poor gentleman. O love thou art a madness, drawing our souls with joy, to kill with sadness.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: So, so, poor souls, how glad they are of liberty. This is a hot house, I do scorch and broil: I'll seek the Elysian fields out, and die there.

div.head: Actus quartus, scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Antonio dressed in Selina's apparel, with Hillaria.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Have I not done my part, wench, with confidence to proceed thus far with thy father? either I am infinitely like my sister, or they are all mad with credulity: but our good fathers are blinded with their passions, and that helps me much: well, I do but think upon the night's work, there lies my masterpiece, I have it, 'tis for thy sake Hillaria, I have assumed this habit, the end will speak it.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But what will you do? Antonio is lost now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well enough, is supposed to go after Selina, and is not returned yet, out of my brotherly love, they will imagine I have but taken a journey in quest of a sister, time enough to return again, and he goes far, that never does wench by story. Enter Bubulcus whetting his sword.here's Bubulcus.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Antonio is gone, no news of him: I am glad of that, I hope he will come no more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How now? what means this? what! sword drawn?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And he is whetting it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: For heaven's sake, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Nay, nothing, nothing, I do but — a —

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: By my virginity you make me afraid, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He means to fight with somebody on my life.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Heaven defend it, good sir, tell me.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Be not afraid, gentlewomen, for I do but, you see.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Whet my long knife, somebody shall smart for't, but —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He does mean to challenge somebody.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I charge you, if you love, tell me who's your enemy.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Nay, nobody , I do not mean to fight, if I live.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Nay, nothing, sweet ladies, be not troubled, I do but sharpen my sword.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Tell me the truth, why?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I was eating oysters tother day, and I had never a knife, and so —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, come, there is some other matter in't, pray tell me.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Welll, you are my friends, if you chance to hear of any man's death shortly, then say Bubulens.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I hope you do not mean to kill any man i'th field, you do make me tremble, I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: No, no, sweetheart, do not tremble, I will but —
Lose my honour? I'll be carved first.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What a capon's this? pray let me persuade you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: And me.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: No, no, 'tis but in vain to persuade me, I'm resolved, if you love me, do not use any arguments:
The Cupidinaean fires burn in my breast,
And like the oven Aetna I am full
Of squibs and crackers. I had almost forgotten —

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The oven Aetna I'll be baked then: what a fury are you in? he looks like the god of war.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: The god of war? I think I have reason. Hillaria, I must, and I will, and all the world shall not hold me.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: But you shall not go away thus, till you be calmer.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: O that I were a flea upon his lip,
There would I suck for ever, and not skip.
