I will carbonado him, his face doth far
Excel all other like a blazing star
We mortals wonder at. Vouchsafe to cast
Off the sparkling diamond eyes thou hast:
Oh let me go on, me thy vowed creature,
That is confounded with thy form and feature.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is the fool mad?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: He has something in his head, and it were out: but here comes our fathers.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Antonio not heard of yet?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: This morning we wanted a bride too, but she was found, marry I cried for her first. Father, come, my brother Antonio is but gone to look his sister: ha, my sweet wench, when shall's to bed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I hope 'tis so, and yet he stays too long. Here's Gorgon: sirrah, where have you been all this day?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Indeed, sir, I have made inquisition, both my tongue and my feet have walked, but my mistress is not to be found or heard of, I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Gorgon, hast lost thy senses? here's Selina.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Mistress, than we are all made. — he capers.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: But sirrah, your master Antonio's gone.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Gone in wine, sir, for joy of his sisters finding again.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Go your ways, sirrah, and either bring me news of him, or look me in the face no more, you'll find we jest not.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Pray, sir, let me take my journey in the morning, the wedding night is fatal: I hope your worship does but jest, I may be drunk too night, and wake early enough to be gone afore day too, I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray, sir, let him stay tonight .

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: By this hand there he is, where? did not I hear his voice?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Away sirrah.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: I have been mad all this while, and now am like to be my own man again: since there is no remedy, gentiles all, good night. Gorgon begins to be a wandering knight.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I cannot be heartily merry: well, let's leave these two without any more ceremonies, 'tis late, all joys be multiplied on my son and daughter: good night, I do comfort myself with hope of Antonio's return, and yet fears are great.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Lights there: so, so, welcome thou much expected night, I do salute thy black brows: come, my Selina, shalt find I have young blood: Hillaria, do service to your mother, make her unready.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis time enough.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: And why should we lose any? I pray thee let her come. I know 'tis your virgin modesty, loath to part with a maidenhead, but it must off: come, prithee be not idle: why, thou knowest I married thee, Selina, as thou lovest me —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, by that love I must entreat you one thing.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Any thing, sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To ratify an ancient vow I made.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Any vows, what is't?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I vowed whenever I married, my husband should not lie with me the first night.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Should anybody else?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not any man.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Come, 'twas a foolish vow, and must be broke. Not lie with me the first night? 'twere a sin beyond incontinency. I had rather lose half my estate, then miss thee but an hour out of mine arms this night.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis but one night.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: O, 'tis an age, a world of time to me: why I have fed of oyster-pies, and rumps of sparrows a whole month, in expectation of the first night, and leave it for a vow?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Indeed you must.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: How? must, come? I know you do but jest, this is but your device to whet me on, and heighten me, as if old age at once hath soaked up all my marrow. Hark you, how old do ye think I am?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Some threescore and seventeen.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Out upon thy judgement: why I am not above, by all computation, six or seven and thirty: I am restored, renewed, when first I loved thee, by this hand I was.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I see than you would tire me, by this beard you must not lie with me tonight .

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: How? nay then I see you'll try my strength: thus I could force you. Antonio throws him down.she has thrown me down, I know not how to take it, nor well how to bear it, my bones ache, a pox a Gasparo, a my conscience I am an old fool: ha? I will see more, and set a good face on't, you know who I am?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, old Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Ha, old? 'tis so, my spirits faint again: what did you marry for?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To make an ass of you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou credulous fool,
Didst thou imagine I should ever love thee,
Or lie with thee? but when I have a child
Would shame the father: o the power of dotage,
That like an inundation doth o'ercome
The little world of man, drown all his reason,
And leave him spoilt, even of his common sense.
Didst think I was a piece of stone sawn out
By carver's art, so cold, so out of soul,
So empty of all fire to warm my blood,
I'd lie with thee, worse than the frigid zone,
Or icicles that hang on beard of winter?
Have I with wearied patience looked to see,
When thou'dst lay violent hands upon thyself;
for being so mad, so impudent to love me,
And wouldst thou bed me too? didst thou not tremble
To dare the holy rites and nuptial tapers?
O impious sacrilege! hence, go waste
Thyself with sorrow, pine that half-starved body,
Until thy bones break thy skin, and fall
To dust before thy face: nay, you shall endure me:
For since you've tied me to you, I will be
Thy constant fury, worse than hags or nightmare,
If thou dost talk of love, or seek to be
At reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Selina, sweet Selina, hear me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sweet? o villainous presumption!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: What will you do?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Save a disease, a labour, make an end of you, come sirrah, swear to observe what I shall impose upon you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: O, any thing, bitter Selina.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: First, you shall never solicit me to lie with you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Never by this hand, and thank you too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stand bore in my presence.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Stark-naked.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Run of my arrands.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: To the world's end.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And keep a whore under my nose, nay, I will allow it.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: If you will have it so, I am content.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Swear, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Flesh, and blood, I do swear.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So, rise. In hope of your conformity, I forbear to let the punishment be equal with your deserts.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: O, I have married a devil, I shall be utterly disgraced, if this be known: pray sweet wife, let me beg one request of you, that you would not discredit me, I will be content to endure your pleasure, do not forsake my house, I beseech you that you would lie with my daughter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Shall you appoint my lodging?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: O no, I do but humbly entreat you will be pleased to lie with my daughter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, since you submit so respectively, I will tender your credit in that point upon your good behaviour, are you not well?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I am the worse for you by forty marks. One thing more, virtuous wife, that you would not tell your father, nor anybody else, how you have beaten me: goodnight, sweet virtuous wife.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha, ha, Hillaria, my way to thee is free, I have beat my passage, and I come to thee.

div.stage: Enter Felice like a shepherdess, Selina, shepherds.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I had thought the woods and such wild groves as these,
Had been the house of rapine, and could not
Afford humanity, beasts, and men like them,
Are wont to make such places desolate:
Did nature make you thus at first, and are
We that have cities, house, and civil laws
More rude than you? or hath all virtue chose
You as divine earth to dwell upon?
Shepherdess, indeed I am in love
With your wild kingdom here, and would not be
A King abroad, if I might be a subject
With such fair nymphs as you.

sp.speaker: 1. Shepherdess
sp.l: O son, you would say so,
When our pleasures all you know:
We are not oppressed with care,
With which you in cities are,
A shepherd is a King, whose throne
Is a mossy mountain, on
Whose top we sit, our crook in hand,
Like a sceptre of command,
Our subjects, sheep grazing below,
Wanton frisking to and fro.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: We nothing fear, awake nor sleep,
but the wolf goddild our sheep,
On a country quill each plays
Madrigals, and pretty lays
Of passions, and the force of love,
And with ditties heaven move.
Birds will listen to our song,
And to leafy arbours throng,
To learn our notes, and mistress name,
Valleys echoing with the same.

sp.speaker: 2. Shepherdess
sp.l: When we hunt, as there is store
Of deer, the trembling hare, and boar,
You would think that you had seen
Gods in shepherd's weeds again.
A hundred pretty nymphs apace
Tripping o'er the lands, and chase,
As many lads, the gentle air
Playing with their dangling hair.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Sometimes we dance a fairy round,
Hand in hand upon the ground,
Shepherds piping, garlands crowning,
With our harmless bosoms drowning.

sp.speaker: 1. Shepherdess
sp.l: Walk unto the silver brook,
You shall need no other hook,
To catch the dancing fish withal,
But a song, or Madrigal.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: When the clouds let fall their showers,
We have at hand a hundred bowers,
Where under sweet-briar, safe are we
And honey-dropping woodbine tree,
Here in spite of storms we tell
Storeys of love, of Philomell,
Of Paris, and the golden ball,
Of echo, and Narcissus fall.

sp.speaker: 3. Shepherdess
sp.l: Here no false-love brings despair,
Jealousy, or suspicion, care,
Always happy most of all
on Silvanus' festival.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: No more, good shepherds, you undo a boy
With the opinion of his happiness:
If a few jewels I have brought with me,
May find acceptance here, I shall bestow them
As freely as your loves have fallen on me.
Nay then, I'll force 'em on you, I have left
To purchase a flock with you.

sp.speaker: 1. Shepherdess
sp.l: We thank you, gentle boy, gooden,
We must to our flocks again.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: But shepherdess, or sister if thou wilt,
O would thou wert, I prithee call me brother,
Hath love a part among you, tell me pray,
What punishment inflict you on false love?
But sure you are exempt from such
A misery: what then
Is her reward, that out of peevishness
Contemns the honest passion of her lover,
Insults upon his virtue, and doth place
Unworthily her affection?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Though such a woman need no curse,
Being one herself, or worse,
Yet we shepherd's use to say,
May she love another day,
And not be loved, die in despair,
And have no other tomb but air.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: A prey, a prey!
Where did you get that face?
That goddess face? it was Selina's once:
How came you by it? did she on her deathbed
Bequeath her beauty as a legacy,
Not willing it should die, but live and be
A lasting death to Infortunio?
O she was cruel, not to bury it with her!
But I am a fool, 'tis Venus and her son,
Where be your bow and arrows, little Cupid?
Didst thou maliciously spend all thy quiver
Upon my heart, and not reserve one shaft
To make Selina love me? Tell me, Venus,
Why did you use me so? you shall no more
Be Queen of love. Stay, stay, Cupid was blind,
How comes he now to see? yes, he did see,
He never could have wounded me so right else.
Why then let fortune have her eyes again,
And all things see how wretched I am made.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: O, is there not within the power of art,
How to restore this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: There is, and out of that experience we
Have in these woods, of simples, I doubt not,
But to apply a remedy.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: He will be worthy of your care herein,
And should he be, which I cannot imagine,
Ingrateful to your skill, I would reward it,
And call you mother, or my sister for it.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: It seems you have some relation to him.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Indeed he is the dearest friend I had:
And if my blood were powerful to restore him,
I'd spend it like a prodigal. I know Selina.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: Ha, do you know Selina? she's married to Rufaldo,
The old usurer, that went to bed afore to his money, and begat forty ith' hundred: now he beds Selina,
And lays his rude hand o'er her sacred breast,
Embraceth her fair body, now he dares
Kiss her, and suck ambrosia from her lip.
Those eyes that grace the day, now shine on him,
He her Endymion, she his silver moon,
The tongue that's able to rock heaven asleep,
And make the music of the spheres stand still,
To listen to the happier airs it makes,
And mend their tunes by it: that voice is now
devoted to his ears, those cheeks, those hands,
Would make gods proud to touch, are by his touch
Profaned every hour: o, this makes me mad,
But I will fit 'em for it, for I'll die,
It may be then she'll weep, and let fall tears
Upon my grave-stone, which shall be of marble,
And hard like her, that if she pour out floods,
No drops shall sink thorough it to soften me,
I will be wrapped in lead to keep out prayers,
For then I know, she'll beg I would be friends:
But then I will be just, and hate her love,
As she did mine, and laugh to see her grieve.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Come, I will fetch Selina to you, if you will sleep.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: Will you then? I will live, and you shall be my best boy.
Come, I scorn to weep, or shed another tear:
Sit down, I'll have a garland for my boy,
Of phoenix feathers: flowers are too mean
To sit upon thy temples; in thy face
Are many gardens, spring had never such:
The roses and the lilies of thy cheeks
Are slips of paradise, not to be gathered,
But wondered at.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: But you said you would sleep: when slept you last?

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: I remember, before I loved, but that I know not when
I slept soundly, and dreamt of gathering nosegays.
'Tis unlucky to dream of herbs and flowers.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: For Selina's sake I'll try my best skill on him, get him to sleep, your presence I see is powerful, yonder's a pleasant arbour, procure him thither while I prepare the herbs, whose precious juice may with heaven's blessing make him well again.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: A thousand blessings on you. Come, sir, go with me, and when you have slept, I'll fetch Salina to you.

sp.speaker: Juf.
sp.p: Prithee do, I am very drowsy: come, I'll dream of some thing, my eyes are going to bed, and leaden sleep doth draw the curtains o'er them.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Will you go with me?

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: Yes, and we will pick a dish of strawberries.

div.stage: Enter Jenkin, having lost his way.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Has almost lost herself in these woods and wildernesses, was very weary of these journeys and travels in footbacks: have not since her comings beheld any reasonable creatures: bless us all, Jocarello is lost too, cannot tell where, in these mazes and labyrinths. Jocarello, so ho.

sp.speaker: Echo.
sp.p: So ho.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Ha, there's somebody's yet, hark you tere, here is a sentilman of Wales, look you, desires very much to have speeches and confabulations with you: where is her?

sp.speaker: Echo.
sp.p: Here is her.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Here is her? knaw not which ways to come to her: pray you tell Jenkin where you be?

sp.speaker: Echo.
sp.p: Booby.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Poobies? was her call her poobies? 'tis very saucy travels, her will teach her better manners and moralities, if her get her in reaches and circumferences of her Welsh blades truly.

sp.speaker: Echo.
sp.p: You lie.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: How, lies and poobies too? hark you, Jenkin was give you mawles and knocks, for your poobies, and lies, and indignities, look for your pates now. Exit with his sword drawn.Enter again.here is nobody's but bushes and briers, look you, all is very quiet: so ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Echo.
sp.p: So ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Her am very much deceived, now it comes into our minds if these voices be not echoes, echo.

sp.speaker: Echo
sp.p: Echo.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, but her marvel much, have her echoes in these countries pray you?

sp.speaker: Echo
sp.p: Yes pray you.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Warrant her 'tis a Welsh echo, was follow Jenkin in loves out of Wales.

sp.speaker: Echo
sp.p: Out of Wales.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, bless us all now, her call to remembrances and memories, her had communications and talkings with this very echoes in Glamorganshire, in de valleys and talls there look you, her am very glad her hath met with echoes, was born in her own countries, hark you, Jenkin was travel hither out of loves and affections to Selina.

sp.speaker: Echo
sp.p: Nay.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Nay, yes very true, pray you tell her, be Selina in these woods, or no?

sp.speaker: Echo
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: No, where is her den, have her taken all these labours and ambulations in vanities? say you, shall Jenkin then go back as he came?

sp.speaker: Echo
sp.p: Ass he came.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Gone? it is not possible, hit may be Selina was turn spirits and be invisible rather, she is not gone verily.

sp.speaker: Echo
sp.p: There you lie.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Lie, very well, you have privileges to give lies and all things in the world, but her will not leave these woods for all dat, her will be pilgrims all tayes of her lives, ere her go without her.

sp.speaker: Echo
sp.p: Go without her.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: How, not love Jenkin? then there is a devil in all female sexes: know very well she promise loves and good wills in times, great while ago, pray you now, her will talk no longer with you. Fare you well echo, pray if you meet her pages, bid her make hasts and expeditions after her. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Echo
sp.p: Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p:
I think Jupiter has snatched up my master Antonio,
to make a Ganymede on him, he is not to be found yet, I have search 't all the taverns ith' town, I am sure, and that method my nose led me to, hoping he had been a good fellow, but, non est iuventus, well, my stock is spent, but with this terrible face a buff jerkin, and a roaring basket-hilt, Gorgon will have a trick of wit to bear his own charges: but here comes a gentleman, to my postures now.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Good your worship bestow a small piece of silver upon a poor soldier, new-come out of the Low-countries, that have been in many hot services, against the Spaniard, the French, and great Turk. I have been shot seven times thorough the body, my eyes blown up with gunpowder, half my skull seared off with a cannon, and had my throat cut twice in the open field: good your worship take compassion upon the caterwauling fortunes of a forlorn gentleman, that have lost the use of my veins: good your generous nature take compassion upon me, I have but four fingers and a thumb upon one hand: can work, and won't: one small piece of grateful silver, to for my lodging, I beseech you venerable sir.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Canst not see?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Only a little glimmering, sir, the beams of your gentility have radiated, and infused light into my poor lanterns, sir.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Can you feel then?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: O, sir, that faculty alone, fortune and nature have left inviolated.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Here's somewhat for thee.
What, can you see now?

div.stage: He kicks him, and Gorgon opens his eyes.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Gasparo, is it you? Pox on your benevolence.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Whence came this project of wit?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p:
From the old predicament. Faith, necessity that has no
law, put me into this habit: my master is turned coward, and ran away from me.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: And thou art turned soldier, to fight with him when you meet again: than thou wantest a master? hark sirrah, what sayest thou to another project?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: O, I could caper for't.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: I am now leaving the world, and going into the country, wilt turn Gipsy, or shepherd? I am for the woods, canst madrigals yet?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Phillis fair, do not disdain
The love of Coridon thy swain.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Excellent I we'll turn shepherds presently, thou shalt be Phillis, and I'll be Coridon: let me alone to provide russets, crook, and Tarbox: they say there's good hospitality in the woods, and songs and pastimes upon sylvan day.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: But that were pretty, shall I be a woman?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: By any means, thou hast a good face already, a little simpering will do it, I'll accommodate thee early, keep thy own counsel, and I'll warrant thee for a maid-marian.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Foot! shall I run into my coats again? go to, put me into what shape you will, I'll play my part: methinks I do feel an hundred rural animals taking up my petticoat already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray forward with your relation.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: As I was saying, having challenged Antonio for the affront he did me before Hillaria, here by heaven, you must say nothing.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Not a syllable.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: He did accept the challenge, and the weapons were soon agreed upon, and we met: but not a word of fighting, if you love me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You are not come to fighting yet yourself, but by the way, what were your weapons?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: A long sword.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twas long ere you could remember it, methinks .

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Soon as we came into the place appointed, we looked about, and saw all clear.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: As clear as day on your side.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: We drew, but not a word of fighting, by this hand.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not by that hand.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: We threw our doublets off, to show we had no coat of mail, or privy shirt upon us, against the laws of duelling, in fine, I bid him say his prayers.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twas well thought upon, and what did you?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I let 'em alone, for I knew I should kill him, and have time enough to say 'em afterwards at my leisure.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: When he had prayed, what then?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: When he had said his prayers, he thought upon it, and let fall words tending to reconcilement: a my conscience, he would have asked me forgiveness, but I stood upon my honour, and would fight with him, and so we stood upon our guard: but not a word of fighting, if you love me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O, by no means, but when did you fight?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Antonio when he saw no remedy, but that I would needs fight with him, and so consequently kill him, made a desperate blow at my head, which I warded with my dagger, better than he looked for, and in return, I cut off his left hand, whereat amazed and fainting, I nimbly seconded it, as you know I am very nimble, and run my rapier into his right thigh, two yards.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Then you were on both sides of him?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Your rapier, did you not say your weapons were long swords?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
But mine was both a sword and rapier, there's it, but not a word of fighting, as you love me: well, not to weary you with the narration of the innumerable wounds I gave him, I cut off every joint from his toe onwards, to his middle, by these hilts, now you may believe me, there
ended Antonio my rival, judge, judge now, whether Bubulcus be valiant or not, but not a word of fighting, as you love me, let it die.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twas very valiantly done.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hark you, sweetheart, do you not remember who this is, that you have discovered this business too? this is Selina, his own sister.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What a rogue was I, not to remember that?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Do not you know that she is my mother in law? nay, nay, pluck up a good heart, what will you do? there's no running away.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Have you never an empty chest?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What, to hide yourself? that I know you would not do for your credit: draw your sword, and stand upon your guard, we know you are valiant, that could kill Antonio so bravely.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Hillaria, if ever you loved me, o, I have made a fair piece of work, would you not tell me it was his sister? o, here they come.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He hath confessed it, sir, your daughter heard it, sir, I charge you lay hands upon that murderer, he hath slain my brother Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Did you hear him confess it?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Here's right, confess and be hanged now.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I must confess I did.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Bubulcus kill Antonio?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: By this hand I do not know how to deny it for my credit.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Nay then lay hands on him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Yes father, Rufaldo, Selina, o, a plague of all coxcombs, what a rogue was I?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will have justice, away with him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I am a lying rascal by this hand.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We must require Antonio from you, sir, or your blood answer his. Away with him, Hillaria.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I'll be hanged then, father. Hillaria, will you see me hanged?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: There is no remedy: would thou hadst killed his sister; I am plagued with her, and dare not speak it for shame, I'll do what I can to get a reprieve for you; nay, and you kill folks, you must e'en take your fortune.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: A curse of all ill fortune, I killed nobody .

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Away, I say, out villain, hence, for I
Do hear my brother's blood for justice cry.

div.head: Actus quintus, scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: I do not know this place, nor who you are,
Nor know I yet myself.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Infortunio?

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: That name I once did answer to, but then
I was not banished to a wilderness,
Nor slept on such a bed. O, if I be
He, whom you call Infortunio.
Tell me how I came hither, dost thou weep?
I prithee tell me, boy, why do those tears
Drown thy fair cheeks? but that they will not show
Manly in me, I'd force my eyes to weep too,
And we would sit upon a bank, and play
Drop-tear, till one were bankrupt. You amaze me:
I ask how I came hither? answer me
With other language, if you do not mean
I came by water, which you might express too
In words as well, nay, better, for you now
Are cruel to yourselves, and murder me:
tell me, or I shall be mad.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: O, stay: that brought Infortunio hither,
You have now told yourself, distraction brought you.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Ha distraction? now you increase my wonder:
Was I mad, or do not you by answering,
Study to make me so? why should I be mad,
Or being so, how came I well again?
For if I dream not, I am well and calm.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You owe this shepherdess for your restore,
Whose skill heaven made so happy.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Did you, fair shepherdess restore me then,
And by your art recover nature's loss?
All my well-beings yours: but yet if you
Could so physician-like cure the disease
Which is but the effect of some distemper,
You then should know the cause: for else you are
Uncertain in your applications.
Pray tell me then, why was I mad?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: This lad can tell you that, better than I,
But if his sorrow will not let his tongue
Deliver it, I'll tell you sir; you were in love.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: With whom, I pray?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: One whom they call Selina.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Ha, Selina? in what a depth of black forgetfulness
Is Infortunio fallen into? Selina,
Could I forget Selina? o shepherdess,
I was not mad till now: for can I be
Myself, and forget her? o, in this question
I am undone: for I do hold myself
And all my understanding by her name,
I am a beggar, she hath purchased all,
Nor am I master of one thought of comfort
I borrow not from her: what curse was fallen
Upon my memory, to forget Selina?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sir, you remember her too well, unless
She would deserve it better.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: It is not in her power to deserve, boy,
For she is now beholding for herself
Unto another. O, this tears my soul,
You did not well to release me of my furies,
And make me sensible again of that
Was my first corrosive, it was unfriendly:
O, 'twas a happiness to be mad, stark mad,
For she being lost, what have I else to lose?
I was all hers, I gave myself away:
And deeds of gift should hold.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Why should you be so passionate? let once reason so late recovered, teach you love yourself, reserved for nobler fortune.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: It is true, I am a very fool in doing so,
And will you be a mistress then, and teach me
How to forget myself? what sayest boy?
Shall I be shepherd too? I will live here
And have thy company, thou art like my love,
Shall we shepherdess?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Come let's sit down awhile, nature hath spread
Her carpets for us here, this is the lowest,
And yet 'tis higher than a palace: pray
Teach me your shepherd's life, now I do long
To be a woodman too, and you shall do
A double cure upon me.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Stay, yonder are some shepherds, let's on this bank sit down and prattle. And how long is't, since your sweetheart forsook you?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: It will be a quarter of a year next grass.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Alas, poor Mopsa, but come, put him out of thy mind, sing him away.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Laugh, and sing him to his grave shall I?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: And never love him more.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: O no, his love like a canker hath eat such a great hole into my heart, I cannot forget him, but I'll sing a song of him.

div.stage: Gorgon sings a song, all this while

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Prithee do.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Here's innocence of all sides, who would live
Out of this commonwealth, where honest swains
Are lords and subjects? Here is no acquaintance
With craft and falsehood, all their souls are clad
In true simplicity: I will take a truce
With care a while, to talk with this poor wench.
Mopsa I heard you named, pray tell me,
Were you in love?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: With whom, forsooth?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: With a gentleman that has proved unkind, forsooth, broken his vows, and oaths, forsooth, he made much of me, time was, before his father died, forsooth, who was a good yeoman, than he kissed me, forsooth, and called surreverence, but now he scorns Mopsa: I was his equal once, and have danced with him upon our church green in a morris ere now.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Alas, alas, has forsaken thee?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: He is now about to commit matrimonial business with a young girl I wiss.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: 'Tis she. I'll have a trick to know it.
Blessings on you shepherdess,
Yet by this hand, you are no less,
You were in love with a fair man,
Crossed by a father, began
This shepherd's life, and russet weed,
Is it not the truth, I read? ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Sir, are you a fortune-teller?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: No, I am fool, and yet I know
Something, though you think not so.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Do you see all this here?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: That and more in this table
sp.l: Lies your story: 'tis no fable,
Not a line within your hand,
But I easily understand:
Your line of life is fair, hard by
Ascends that of prosperity,
But broken in the midst to th' mount
Of Saturn here, which ill we count,
Ha, triangle and mercurial line?
But Venus is no friend of thine.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: How now, palmistry? believe him not.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: In your face your fate is written,
You loved a woman, she not you,
You know whether I say true,
Her name began with s. but she,
Shall never be enjoyed by thee,
She's married now to one that's old,
But very rich: your fortune's told.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Beshrew me he has cunning.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Do you believe him sir?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Believe him? nay, you may believe him, he's abomination cunning man, he told me my fortune as right as if he had been in my belly.

sp.speaker: Shepherdess
sp.p: Does thy fortune lie in thy belly then, sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Partly, sir, as other women's fortunes do.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Damsel, you have yet a fate
Will make you wonder more thereat,
By collection, I dare prove,
That his name, whom you did love,
Began with G. but 'tis too true,
He hath slain himself for you.
sp.p: Felice, come again, do not believe me, I told thee false, I did but try to gain a knowledge of thee: thy stars owe thee more happiness, Felice, look up, see thy friend alive, I am Gasparo. Foot, I ha' made fair work.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Ha, 'tis Gasparo.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Have I found thee, oh wench, thou wert unjust,
Too much unjust, thus to absent thyself
From Gasparo, thy cruel father since
Hath wept enough to wash away his error.
Fates, I do thank you, for this blessed direction.
But Infortunio, I am sorry now,
I read the truth of thy unhappiness,
It is too true, Selina is beyond
Your sphere of hope, pardon, worthy sir,
The shape I took, was not to mock your fortunes,
But try mine own. And have I found the wench?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: O, no, no, your suit is in vain, hands off, shepherds.

sp.speaker: 1. Shepherdess
sp.p: I will make thee amends and marry, prithee sweet Mopsa, beautiful Mopsa.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Beauty! I do confess I have reasonable beauty, for black and white, for all other colours are but compounded of them: but the truth is, I cannot so soon forget my old love; though he hath proved false unto me, Mopsa will prove true unto him: o, and it were not for shame, now I would die for love.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Be not dejected, sir, you have a fate
Doth smile upon you, I have a little skill.
In that this gentleman seemed to have some knowledge,
I must needs cross his judgement, and pronounce
You are more happy.

lg.l: Let not ought your soul annoy,
You that virgin shall enjoy,
That you first loved, who doth wait
To make your wishes fortunate,
And ere sun twice declines to West,
You may be with marriage blessed.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: The boy is mad.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Do not undo, sweet boy, the benefit
Thou hast already done me, thou dost utter impossibilities.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Then with one argument I can easily
Take off your wonders, look on thy Selina,
That on the wedding morn, forsook Rufaldo,
Touched with a sense of thy indignities,
Thus to obscure me from all curious search
And inquisition, but not hoping ever
To be made thine, now if true love maintain
The opinion you pretend, thus in your arms
I pour myself.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: It is Selina. O, I am rent in pieces
With joy and wonder.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Hark you, sir, do not believe him,
Let not passion make you a mockery.
sp.p: Is not Selina married to Rufaldo? then am I goose-giblet: I should have been at church with 'em, but for a crotchet that I had in my pate all the morning: I spoke with her father yesterday, and from his mouth I heard, Selina was very well, I think I do not dream, indeed now I call to memory, he said Selina was missed two or three hours ath' wedding morn; some figary, I know not what: and Antonio, as I supposed, gone in quest of her, not heard of since: but Selina is sure Rufaldo's wife, or some devil in her likeness has abused them all with credulity. This is true, sir, therefore be not easy, do not deserve more pity, this boy is mad, a juggling boy.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Shall I not be believed then for myself? am I refused now?

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: It cannot be she: troth boy, thy conceit took me at first with much credulity: but here's our nature's weakness, apt to credit what we affect: were there not too much against it, thou mightst deceive me: o no, Infortunio is given up, lost to all felicity.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Since then you put me, sir, to prove myself, let me not be lost, I will not call you what I desire, nor name you sister: give me leave to find myself, I know not where I am yet: my brother Antonio gone? what fury hath assumed Selina's shape?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Come, put on a man's spirit, Mopsa.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Well, sir, in regard you are soExit cum Inf. and Felportunate, although I have forsworn marriage, if you desist constant, you may chance to have a lick at my maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I have it, my brother's lost:
I'll send a shepherd in Antonio's name,
To invite my father hither, and that incubus.
I vow not to forsake these plains, till I
Possess myself, or be rejected quite,
Suspend thy passions then awhile, Selina,
Tomorrow is the shepherd's holiday,
Which they solemnize with rural pleasures,
'Twill draw them sooner: ha, are they gone?
I will not leave 'em, with this thread I shall
Tread o'er the labyrinth, and discover all.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Antonio slain? hapless Cornelio,
My hopes were treasured up in him, the staff
And comfort of my age, and is he gone?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hast sent for Bubulcus?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have,
Father, let not too much passion soil that temper
Hath been observed in old Cornelio.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why, was not he thy brother? canst thou
Thou hast so little share in young Antonio,
That thou darest speak of comfort?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sir, on my life Antonio is not dead.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Bubulcus, on my soul's a very coward,
And durst as well attempt to take a prey
Out of a tiger's jaws, as see a sword
With patience bent against him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: But cowards in despair prove desperate, and most unhappy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A my conscience I could beat him into a mousehole.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Nay, I could beat him, and I am sure you can beat me, would I were well rid of you: 'tis a double misery to be abused, and dare not speak out.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Here's Bubulcus.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Not guilty, not guilty, and please your worships, let me not be hanged for a lie of mine own making: 'tis well known I am a stinking coward: not guilty, I beseech you; I never drew sword in anger in my life: if you hang me, you undo me for ever.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Look you, sir, 'tis clear.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: My conscience is as clear as crystal: not guilty, my lord, I beseech you —

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Didst not thou kill Antonio then?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Let me be hanged if I did.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Stay, he'll confess.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I confess I told a lie, thinking to have got some credit: but if ever I saw Antonio, since he gave me two or three kicks, which I deserved well enough, broil me ath' coals. Mercy, o mercy: do not cast me away upon the hangman now, in the pride of my youth: not guilty, my lord.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Howsoever fear of death possess him so, I see the murder in his eyes.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: My eyes? would they were out then: do you see murder in my eyes? are my eyes bloodshot?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: His very hand doth show a guiltiness, look how it trembles.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: The fear of hanging hath put my whole body into palsy: my hands guilty? I can wash my hands clean of it, I never killed a fly. By this hand, not guilty.

sp.speaker: Shepherdess
sp.p: Which is Cornelio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This: what's the matter? what makes this shepherd here?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I am Cornelio: is it with me thou wouldst?

sp.speaker: Shepherdess
sp.l: If your name Cornelio be,
Contentment and felicity
I bring you: I am sent from one
That doth call himself your son,
Young Antonio, who thus low
Would beg your blessing, prays that no
Affliction too much you dismay
For his absence, bade me say,
If you deign suspend your care,
A few hours, and repair
Unto the place of shepherds by,
To grace their pleasures with your eye,
Antonio will himself declare,
Faithfully what causes were
Of his absence, and requite
These dolours with a fresh delight:
And so farewell. This is all:
Back again I hear them call.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: O stay awhile.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He's gone, sir: did I not tell you, Antonio was not dead? but this is strange.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Do I not dream?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Antonio among the shepherds? if he be there, I am dressed i'faith: by any means, go sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Is Antonio alive again?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Yes verily, alive again, let not the hangman fright away your wits any longer.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I hope I shall choose my own gallows then. Hillaria, you would not believe me: did I look as I had killed anybody ? now I hope you will hold me for an innocent hereafter.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Babulcus, pray let us have your company,
It doth concern your freedom. Antonio living?
Rufaldo, let us make a merry day on't,
If it be true. If? I do sin against
Discretion to distrust it. O my stars,
I do acquit you all your injuries,
If you possess me of Antonio.
Never did man to bliss more willing go.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I am glad I am reprieved: come Hillaria.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twere pretty if Antonio be multiplied: here's tricks indeed, I am resolved to see what will the end of this confusion be.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Never was Jenkin in such wilderness, her have walked and travelled create deal of miles in these woods: but her can find no end nor evasions, look you: her have read in histories, and relations, and chronicles, very famous knights, and prave sentilmen of valours and chivalries have been enchanted, look you, in castles and very strange dwellings, and towers, and solitary places, now was have create fears and suspicions, lest Jenkin was fallen into some wisheries and conjurations, and was enchanted, bless us all in these deserts and wildernesses for her valours and magnanimities.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: So ho, ho, master Jenkin.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: It is our pages again. Jocarello, where have you been? you are very tilligent boys, to lose your master thus.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: I was lost myself, had not a shepherd by chance found me, and carried me into his house under the ground, where with a great many of shepherdess we sat up all night in making garlands for some show and pastimes to be done this day, which they call their festival: pray, sir, since we have run a wild-goose chase so long, let's stay one day to see these sports and dancings.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p:
Sports and dances, say you? take pleasures and delectations in dances? Very well, Jenkin was knaw how to dance herself, was pred in all sentilmans qualities,
look you, her will make no peregrinations back till all be done, and it may be, was shake her legs in capers too, look you now.

div.stage: Enter Cornelio, Rufaldo, Antonio, Bubulcus, Hillaria.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Master Jenkin, you are well met in these parts, I perceive you are early this morning, to partake the pastimes of our shepherds.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Good tayes and salutations, and cret deal of felities come to all your urships.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Sir, my name is master Bubulcus, and I am as good a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: As who pray you? do you make comparisons?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I do embrace your familiarities, and remain your truest worm.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Not too much worms, nor familiarities pray you: ha pages, here is Selina's in her own apparels and vestments, all was very true as our countrywoman echoes was make reports: Selina was gone back again: very well: mistress Selina's was very full of joys and exhillarations, to see you in these places, you knaw how greatly and ardently Jenkin was taken with your peauties, and pulchritudes, cret while ago: pray when did you make returns out of these woods? Jenkin had knowledge, and saw you in your shepherd apparels, and was make ambulations after you hither, out of mere amours and affections as her was true sentilman.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I make return out of these woods? I entered them but now.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Well, you desire not to have things declared, and published, her was keepe all silences.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Upon my life you are mistaken quite in this, master Jenkin.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: O, pray you make not Jenkin ridiculous, and derisions, look you, shall hear no more of that matters, call you only to memories you promised loves to Jenkin, pray you in matrimonies create while ago.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I deny not that, sir, but I know not why you have
long neglected me, and I am now married to Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Rufaldo's? hit is not possible.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Father, he says it is impossible Selina should be your wife.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: How, not my wife? I would fain see that.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Is Selina your wife's in truths and verities pray you?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Do you make question? My wife? I think there is some reason, she is my very dear wife, I will assure you sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: He has got a boy by this time.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: A boy? well, I have got something, a pox a your fingers. How sayest? is not something, done sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, in my conscience something is done.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Jenkin was never all his days have such injuries and contumelies put upon her: was ever sentilman thus abused? have her made repetitions and genealogies of her blood, for no matrimonies? Jenkin has peat the bushes, and Rufaldo's has get the pirds. Hum! her love not to make quarrels and prabbles, but Jenkin could fight with any podies in the whole urld, all weapons, from the long pikes to the welsh-hookes, look you now, no matrimonies? her welsh-blood is up, look you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Master Bubulcus.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Master Blew-pottles, have you any stomachs or appetites to have any ploughs or knogs upon your costards, look you?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No great stomach at this time, sir, I thank you: alas, I have 'em every day, they are no novelties with me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Come, master Jenkin, I now perceive you loved my daughter, if you had acquainted me in time, I should not have been unwilling to have called you son, but since 'tis too late, let your wisdom check impatience: I know you are of a noble temper, howsoever passion may a little cloud your virtues, let's be all friends I pray.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Here is very could honest words, yes, look you, Jenkin is in all amities and friendships, but —

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
O, no more shooting at that but: hark, I hear
the shepherd's music, and voice too, let's sit down I pray, Antonio keep thy word.

div.stage: Music. Enter shepherds and shepherdess with garlands.

lg.l: Woodmen shepherds, come away,
This is Pan's great holiday,
Throw off cares,
With your heaven aspiring airs
Help us to sing
While valleys with your echoes ring.
Nymphs that dwell within these groves,
Leave your arbours, bring your loves,
Gather poesies,
Crown your golden hair with roses,
As you pass
Foot like fairies on the grass.
Joy drown our bowers, Philomell,
Leave of Tereus' rape to tell,
Let trees dance,
As they at Thracian lyre did once,
Mountains play,
This is the shepherd's holiday.

div.stage: Dance. The song ended, enter a mask of satires etc. and dance. Enter a shepherdess with a white rod.

sp.speaker: 1. Shepherdess
sp.l: Post hence satires and give way,
For fairer souls to grace the day,
And this presence, whip the air
With new ravishings, hence with care,
By the forelock hold time fast,
Lest occasion slip too fast
Away from us, joys here distil.
Pleasures all your bosoms fill.

div.stage: Enter Infortunio, Selina, Gasparo, Felice, Gorgon, shepherd.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Fair nymph, vouchsafe the honour to dance with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Troth, sir, I cannot dance.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: We know you are Selina.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Your hand, fairest.

sp.speaker: 1. Shepherdess
sp.p: Disdain not, gentle sir.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Pibble pables, with all her hearts, look you.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Noble sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Fair lady, at your service.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: I will not change.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Which is Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: It will break out anon.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You are a thief.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You have robbed Selina.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then I'll make restitution, what are you?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The devil you are! faith, deal honestly with me, and I'll be true to thee: who art?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I am Selina by my hopes of heaven.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha, sister then!

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I have no brother but Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And I am he. O happiness!

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: If thou beest Antonio, what made thee assume my habit?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Of that anon. Lives Infortunio?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: He's here, and with him Gasparo and my sister the lost Felice.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I am ravished with this wonder.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Keep your face constant: the music calls.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ha, what means this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Selina.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Your blessing, sir, we are your children.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Who's this?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I am Selina, sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And I am Antonio.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Amazement: thou Antonio? he Selina?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Ha, how's this, my wife become a man? I confess she played the man with me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: But who is this?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: I am Felice, sir, your long lost daughter,
Found out by Gasparo, unto whom my vows
In heaven were long since sacred, and I beg
Once more he may be mine.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: As I to be possessed
By Infortunio here.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Stay children, stay: take heed, you do not know
What strength of joy my fainting age can bear:
You fall in too full showers, like swelling Nile
These comforts will exceed the narrow banks
Of my poor frailty: rise, enjoy your wishes,
And my blessings be multiplied upon you. Ha!
Rufaldo, here's Felice my lost girl,
Take her, take her, Gasparo. Selina,
Art not thou Rufaldo's wife?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No, sir, I ventured that, he knows me well,
Hillaria and I were bed fellows, at his request.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How? Hillaria and you bedfellows? I'd laugh at that.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I am abused, disgraced, undone.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Nay, Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why then, it seems you were Antonio, that I killed so, and you have, as a man should say, line with Hillaria beforehand.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I am not behind hand.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Nay, and you have tickled her before and behind, tickle her all over for Bubulcus.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Hark you, is there another Selina's? bless us all, here is very prave love-tricks, look you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Blessing on him: why he hath made stockfish on me, he has beaten away all my inclination to give my blessing.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Come, upon recollection, you must make it a bargain: they have, it seems, bought and sold already, 'tis past recovery, he shall be worthy of her.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, that you may with more alacrity let fall your blessings: know, our bloods are pure, Antonio and your daughter are as chaste from any sinful act, as when we were first mantled after birth.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Ha, sayest so?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twas none of my fault, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Then my blessings to you: come, you're both my children.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Amen, and mine: why I am rapt beyond myself with joys. Infortunio, fate hath effected that I begged of heaven in many prayers for you, o my blisses.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: So, so, I am gulled, my house taken o'er my head?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Sir, you know who I am, I am yet walking terra incognita, I have a great mind to Bubulcus, you know what I have suffered for him, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Let me alone, so, so: then pleasures run with a stream upon us, but if we shall make a full day on't, here's one more to meet with her match, this poor virgin hath been long in love with Bubulcus: troth, sir, look upon her at length pitifully complaining: alas good soul, be honest at length: prithee do, and marry her, you know what has passed between you, 'tis a handsome wench.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Umh, I do remember she was in love with me, and so was twenty more: what's that to me? Alas, would you have me descend so low?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: O, sir, you sung another song in my mother's dairy, when we sat up all night together, and had a sack posset.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I do remember such a thing, but what's that? I'll take't upon me.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: I beseech you, gentlemen, speak for me, for I will have him, I am ashamed to show my reasons.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Very small ones: away you dirty quean.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: What, has he got thee with child?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: More than that, sir.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Has he had any bastards?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Indeed mistress, I'll tell you; he hath begotten three children of my body.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Fie upon't, no less than three bastards.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How? nay, she lies falsely, I got but two, so many I will acknowledge, because they shall not doubt my sufficiency, had I any more than two? speak you lying whore

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Sir, I tender your credit, there is but two ways either you must marry her, or give her a piece of money that's the easiest way, she is poor: for your reputation —

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What do you think will content the whore?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Hark you, best for you, make some satisfactions to this gentlewoman, or Senkin was learne you more ho and behaviours towards these vmans, warrant you master blue pottles.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: A matter of twenty or thirty pieces, you can spare them.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: You strumpet, here's twenty pieces for you: do you hear? keep well the boys then: but you shall swear, before these gentlemen, you will never claim marriage: there, be an honest woman hereafter.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Yes, bear witness, gentlemen, I do accept his wise benevolence, and will never trouble him with marriage — while Gorgon lives.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Gorgon?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Your servant, and your pardons: nay, Gorgon has had his devices and vagabunduloes as well as the best on ye: give you all joy, I wish you wit, sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I am fooled of all sides, was I born a fool?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Stay you, master double colours, there be more ▪ fools in the business as yourself: well Jenkin, were even best make shurneyes back into her own countries, and never put credits or conferences in any woman's in the whole urld: they all lie and cozen, and make derisions out all measures.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: Nay, nay, gentlemen, let's all together
We'll drown all discontents this day with 〈◊〉 ▪
Let's take up all our fates then, and proclaim
This 〈◊〉 new festivals in Hymen's name.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Stay a little, and I'll along with you. Since I have missed my wench, I'll ask these gentlemen's good wills to a second match, in stead of an epilogue.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Why, how now? what, are you mad? will you speak the epilogue? though you have played a fool in the play, you will not show yourself an ass before all this company. The epilogue? I hope I am the wiser ath' two, and the better read in compliment.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Hark you, master double-colours, and you goody Gorgon's, here is one wiser, asses you both, to pronounce the epilogue, warrant you, and one, that knows — to speak in as good English, gentlemen, now sans compliment.

div.l: Our love-tricks have been shown, and we attend
To know 〈…〉 acceptance crown the end,
The world is full of 〈◊〉 but it will be
To these of 〈…〉 contentment dwell
On you we 〈…〉 play 〈…〉 well,
Which 〈…〉 call, that we might prove
〈…〉 your love.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
